quiz.name: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 4 Session 2
quiz.subtopic: 2026 CFA Program LI Mock Exam 4 Session 2
instructions:
CFA Level 1 Mock Exam Instructions

This CFA Level I mock exam (Session 2) is in English and contains 90 multiple-choice questions. You will have 2 hours and 15 minutes to complete the exam and review your answers. 

Before You Begin

Please note the following in regards to this examination:

  • International Financial Reporting Standards (IFRS) apply unless otherwise noted.
  • "The Code" refers to the CFA Institute Code of Ethics.
  • "The Standards" refers to the CFA Institute Standards of Professional Conduct.
  • "GIPS® standards" refers to the Global Investment Performance Standards.

How to Answer Questions

  • Each question is numbered and includes multiple-choice options (lettered A, B, C).
  • For each question:
    • Decide which answer is best.
    • Select the corresponding letter.
    • Click 'Next' to move to the next question.
  • You may:
    • Select only one answer per question.
    • Skip questions or return to questions by selecting the ‘Previous’ or the ‘Next’ buttons.

After Completing the Exam

  • Click 'Submit' when you are finished.
  • Once submitted, you may review all questions and your selected answers.
  • Only selected responses will be scored.
  • Your score will reflect the number of correct answers only.
    • No penalty for incorrect answers.
    • It is to your advantage to answer every question, even if you are unsure of the correct answer.
  • If you finish early, use the remaining time to review questions you are unsure about.

Click the 'Begin' button when you are ready to start the mock exam.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-FI-Whitmer-05
entry.itemBody: A measure of the sensitivity of a bond’s price to a change in a specific maturity segment of the benchmark yield curve best defines:

answerFeedback.157c7dfa-4ccc-4292-ba82-82ba2a413e7a: Incorrect because modified duration has an important application in risk measurement: It provides an estimate of the percentage price change for a bond given a change in its yield-to-maturity.
answerFeedback.197e54cf-5729-4290-845a-a5801734f214: Correct because key rate duration (or partial duration) is a measure of a bond’s sensitivity to a change in the benchmark yield curve at a specific maturity segment. In contrast to effective duration, key rate durations help identify 'shaping risk' for a bond—that is, a bond’s sensitivity to changes in the shape of the benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.eec2c5c0-fb74-4b0b-9768-518b9f1a7e9a: Incorrect because an approach to assess the interest rate risk of a bond is to estimate the percentage change in price given a change in a benchmark yield curve—for example, the government par curve. This estimate, which is very similar to the formula for approximate modified duration, is called the effective duration. The effective duration of a bond is the sensitivity of the bond’s price to a change in a benchmark yield curve. Effective duration measures interest rate risk in terms of a parallel shift in the benchmark yield curve (ΔCurve), not a change in its shape.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Glover-04
entry.itemBody: An analyst assumes that a company's market share gains will decline smoothly to zero over the next five years. Which of the following best describes this forecast approach and object?

answerFeedback.07a603c2-2cdd-4ec9-ad40-a940c0d4d104: Correct because a company's market share is a top-down revenue driver and assuming that this object will converge to zero over the next five years is consistent with the historical base rates and convergence forecasting approach.
answerFeedback.1c084d82-843e-4795-9000-22156fe647af: Incorrect because assuming that a forecast object will converge to zero over the next five years is consistent with the historical base rates and convergence forecasting approach, not the analyst's discretionary forecast approach.
answerFeedback.facbd8da-bf39-43fd-8458-8295ec208b8e: Incorrect because a company's market share is a top-down, not bottom-up, revenue driver.

choices.itemBody: A. Discretionary forecast of a top-down revenue driver
B. Historical base rates and convergence forecast of a top-down revenue driver
C. Historical base rates and convergence forecast of a bottom-up revenue driver

entry.title: ITEM_20170606104
entry.itemBody: A portfolio's investment strategy relies on a particular element of the tax code to produce superior after-tax returns for high-net-worth individuals. Because of this strategy, the portfolio most likely faces a high level of:

answerFeedback.1d26487d-d5be-47c0-a780-d5483658f1bb: Incorrect because model risk is the risk of using the wrong model for analysis or the risk of using the right model incorrectly.
answerFeedback.c3b430c3-ef28-49b5-96ba-202751cac35b: Correct because tax risk, the risk that the tax code could change, along with regulatory and accounting risks together form compliance risk.
answerFeedback.c5d1e174-4180-40d8-a5fc-8426bff2353e: Incorrect because legal risk is the risk of being sued or the risk that a court will not uphold an agreement.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 03AHC
entry.itemBody: The expected return for a security is equal to the market’s risk premium. If the risk-free rate is positive and the CAPM holds, the beta of the security is:

answerFeedback.79c94a3b-534c-4279-824a-96e5dca4e457: Incorrect because the CAPM equation is E(Ri) = Rf + β[E(Rm) – Rf]. Therefore, if beta is equal to 1, the security’s return will be higher than the market risk premium.
answerFeedback.9e89ac3a-e189-424d-a63b-045ababa35c8: Incorrect because the CAPM equation is E(Ri) = Rf + β[E(Rm) – Rf]. Therefore, if beta is greater than 1, the security’s return will be higher than the market risk premium.
answerFeedback.fdcdde44-dee6-4979-b288-0a48ce772e45: Correct because the CAPM equation is E(Ri) = Rf + β[E(Rm) – Rf]. Therefore, the beta of the security has to be less than 1 in order for the security’s return to be the same as the market risk premium, given that the risk-free rate is positive.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Tsependa-02
entry.itemBody: With regard to their investment in pension plans, employees with defined contribution plans accept:

answerFeedback.6431c84c-28f2-4695-a57a-d64131817518: Incorrect because the key to a defined contribution plan is that the employee accepts the investment and inflation risk, not only inflation risk.
answerFeedback.a4c86f5d-e2cd-4594-bcff-eea035c85e8a: Incorrect because the key to a defined contribution plan is that the employee accepts the investment and inflation risk, not only investment risk.
answerFeedback.db2d9ca8-94e6-4e9f-9817-d6add3817deb: Correct because the key to a [defined contribution plan is that the employee accepts the investment and inflation risk and is responsible for ensuring that there are enough assets in the plan to meet their needs upon retirement.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-FI-Moustra-06
entry.itemBody: Redemption regimes are a feature of:

answerFeedback.1318e27d-0071-4e89-bdfa-058ab038c416: Correct because covered bonds are similar to ABS, but they differ because of their dual recourse nature, strict eligibility criteria, dynamic cover pool, and redemption regimes in the event of sponsor default. Redemption regimes exist to align the covered bond’s cash flows as closely as possible with the original maturity schedule in the event of default of a covered bond’s financial sponsor.
answerFeedback.648eb227-93fe-4dd7-8ee0-014468501cd5: Incorrect because redemption regimes is not a feature of auto loan asset backed securities. In the case of ABS, the financial institution that originates loans transfers securitized assets to a bankruptcy-remote special legal entity, but the pool of underlying assets in a covered bond (or “cover pool”) remains on the financial institution’s balance sheet, against which covered bondholders retain a top-priority claim. Covered bonds are similar to ABS, but they differ because of their dual recourse nature, strict eligibility criteria, dynamic cover pool, and redemption regimes in the event of sponsor default.
answerFeedback.dab3240b-3533-4457-b709-5dbe8686e28b: Incorrect because redemption regimes is not a feature of commercial mortgage-backed securities. In the case of ABS, the financial institution that originates loans transfers securitized assets to a bankruptcy-remote special legal entity, but the pool of underlying assets in a covered bond (or “cover pool”) remains on the financial institution’s balance sheet, against which covered bondholders retain a top-priority claim. Covered bonds are similar to ABS, but they differ because of their dual recourse nature, strict eligibility criteria, dynamic cover pool, and redemption regimes in the event of sponsor default.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-08
entry.itemBody: Private equity securities most likely:

answerFeedback.11364312-9ca8-4c10-8289-ceec12601017: Incorrect because private equity securities do not have “market determined” quoted prices.
answerFeedback.b5627890-05f5-49ac-b878-f984f2aef3bb: Incorrect because private equity securities are not listed on public exchanges, and there is no active secondary market for these securities.
answerFeedback.fb4775ea-a30a-4e32-8070-e4a6e4c2f6a8: Correct because private equity securities do not have “market determined” quoted prices, are highly illiquid, and require negotiations between investors in order to be traded.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Alt-Shaw-20
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a hedge fund:

Beginning-of-year assets under management (AUM) $100,000,000
Annual gross return 15%
Management fee, based on end-of-year AUM 2%
Incentive fee 20%
Hard hurdle rate 5%

If the incentive fee is based on returns net of management fees, total fees for the year are:

answerFeedback.4b17ed50-aca1-4a3d-b15c-fc8bce2d5427:
Correct because the partnership agreement usually specifies that the performance (incentive) fee is earned only after the fund achieves a return known as a hurdle rate. The hurdle rate is a minimum rate of return that the GP must exceed in order to earn the performance fee. 

Ending Value: $100 million × (1 + 15%) = $115 million

Management fee based on end of year AUM: $115 million × 2% = $2.30 million 

Hurdle: $100 million × 5% = $5 million 
Return after fees and hurdle: $115 million – $100 million – $2.30 million – $5 million = $7.70 million

Incentive fee: $7.70 million × 20% = $1.54 million 
Manager's total fees: $2.30 million + $1.54 million = $3.84 million.
answerFeedback.7bed5ab8-1c87-4a84-9359-8b9620b6a721:
Incorrect because it omits the hurdle from the incentive fee calculation:

$100 million × (1 + 15%) = $115 million

$115 million × 2% = $2.30 million management fee

$115 million – $100 million – $2.30 million = $12.70 million

$12.70 million × 20% = $2.540 million incentive fee
Manager's total fees = $2.30 million + $2.54 million = $4.84 million.
answerFeedback.e0174d16-ba0b-4da3-9d89-7559ecf313bb:
Incorrect because it fails to net out management fees from the incentive fee calculation:

$100 million × (1 + 15%) = $115 million

$115 million × 2% = $2.30 million management fee

$100 million × 5% = $5 million hurdle
$115 million – $100 million – $5 million = $10 million

$10 million × 20% = $2.0 million incentive fee
Manager's total fees = $2.30 million + $2.0 million = $4.30 million.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601044
entry.itemBody: The price of a forward contract most likely:

answerFeedback.1f9d95dc-566b-46ae-99d2-639465ef3a49: Incorrect. The price of a forward contract is not affected by market conditions. It is set as part of the contract specifications.
answerFeedback.aad3dcd8-e3eb-49a5-83a7-9048047e9321: Correct. The price of a forward contract remains constant throughout the life of the contract. It is set as part of the contract specifications.
answerFeedback.aebb52af-5291-4c85-a58e-89d1a5dc1a7e: Incorrect. The price of a forward contract is not affected by market conditions. It is set as part of the contract specifications.

choices.itemBody: A. decreases as the price of the underlying goes up.
B. is constant and set as part of the contract specifications.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-PM-Zhang-04
entry.itemBody: With respect to risk governance, which of the following statements is most accurate?

answerFeedback.47e76337-2c18-4034-ab08-933b6e042028: Incorrect because enterprise risk management (focusing risk activities on the objectives, health, and value of the whole organization) requires that the entire economic balance sheet of the business be considered, not just the assets or one part of the business in isolation.
answerFeedback.67f4ad46-ae58-461a-af32-f8138d3d903d: Correct because an individual, whose wealth consists not only of financial assets but also of valuable human capital, might prefer that risk allocation decisions be made in view of both forms of capital, optimizing her total wealth.
answerFeedback.9ff8ded3-7b64-4a12-917e-a48ea2238cb9: Incorrect because with increased reliance on technology, more time and effort must be allotted to test data, models, and results in order to avoid the ironic outcome of the risk of errors coming from within risk systems.

choices.itemBody: A. With more usage of technology, less time is required to test data and models
B. Enterprise risk management requires that assets and liabilities be considered in isolation
C. Both financial assets and human capital can be considered in an individual's risk allocation

entry.title: ITEM_20170516099
entry.itemBody: Compared with unregulated markets, regulated markets are best characterized by:

answerFeedback.cb6767e3-d5e4-4e24-b8ff-dd649bccc1f0: Incorrect because regulations help to level the playing field for market participants. When participants believe that markets are fair, they continue to trade in the market, thus increasing trading volumes.
answerFeedback.d86d69ed-4323-4a2a-af96-578d36fdafa3: Incorrect because regulated markets tend to be more operationally efficient, which leads to lower transactions costs.
answerFeedback.db69ca96-beee-44b4-b3df-03697ecd2092: Correct because regulated markets are more informationally efficient, there are fewer arbitrage opportunities.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Horvath-02
entry.itemBody: Challenges in constructing fixed-income indexes most likely include that:

answerFeedback.1baceff0-cea4-4444-88b3-e04fc922f838: Incorrect because a challenge in index construction is that fixed-income markets are predominantly dealer markets.
answerFeedback.7dee01d4-8d8e-4ebd-9531-46dc04b3b22f: Incorrect because the number of fixed-income securities is many times larger than the number of equity securities. To represent a specific fixed-income market or segment, indexes may include thousands of different securities. Over time, these fixed-income securities mature, and issuers offer new securities to meet their financing needs, leading to turnover in fixed-income indexes.
answerFeedback.90e09360-f265-4bf9-8a53-63477fce2731: Correct because in the fixed income market many securities do not trade frequently and, as a result, are relatively illiquid. As a result, index providers must contact dealers to obtain current prices on constituent securities to update the index or they must estimate the prices of constituent securities using the prices of traded fixed-income securities with similar characteristics.

choices.itemBody: A. there is a small number of securities.
B. securities are relatively illiquid compared to equities.
C. fixed-income markets are predominantly order-driven markets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-McDonald-19
entry.itemBody: The first date a buyer of shares is not entitled to an announced dividend is the:

answerFeedback.0749585b-4155-40c8-acae-3e95e3661ad2: Incorrect because buyers of a company’s shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company’s share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend. This is followed by the holder-of-record date (also called the owner-of-record date, shareholder-of-record date, record date, date of record, or date of book closure), the date that a shareholder listed on the company’s books will be deemed to have ownership of the shares for purposes of receiving the upcoming dividend.
answerFeedback.2538f07a-fad8-4b0a-a132-c10b6f92ea97: Incorrect because first is the declaration date, the day that the company issues a statement declaring a specific dividend. Next comes the ex-dividend date (or exdate), the first date that a share trades without (i.e., “ex”) the dividend.
answerFeedback.4d10af89-f215-44f7-8bf0-ecaf486098e2: Correct because buyers of a company’s shares on the ex-dividend date are no longer eligible to receive the upcoming dividend, all else being equal, on that day the company’s share price immediately decreases by the amount of the foregone dividend.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427046
entry.itemBody: Commodity futures prices are most likely in backwardation when:

answerFeedback.13b18691-07f5-4b06-8dc9-3430b41e381b: Correct. In backwardation, futures prices are lower than spot prices, that is, the commodity forward curve is downward sloping. This scenario occurs when the convenience yield is high. Futures price ≈ Spot price (1 + r) + Storage costs – Convenience yield.
answerFeedback.63d8dc7b-4475-40e8-b0a2-b4a957fba7b8: Incorrect. Futures price ≈ Spot price (1 + r) + Storage costs – Convenience yield. Thus, high storage costs contribute to an upward sloping commodity forward curve.
answerFeedback.799643ba-5874-466e-a562-744f48d98643: Incorrect. Futures price ≈ Spot price (1 + r) + Storage costs – Convenience yield. Thus, high interest rates contribute to an upward sloping commodity forward curve.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427003
entry.itemBody: In the context of venture capital financing, seed-stage financing most likely supports:

answerFeedback.013ee47b-507d-401c-8f97-dd496d073905: Incorrect because this activity is supported by early-stage financing, not seed-stage financing. Early-stage financing (early-stage VC), or start-up stage financing, goes to companies moving toward operation but prior to commercial production or sales, in both of which early-stage financing may be injected to initiate.
answerFeedback.0661c7ba-6f49-454b-87ba-595a044b4918: Incorrect because this activity is supported by pre-seed capital, not seed-stage financing. Pre-seed capital, or angel investing, is capital provided at the idea stage. Funds may be used to develop a business plan and to assess market potential.
answerFeedback.91643ece-6145-488a-8c60-893a14f8856d: Correct because seed-stage financing, or seed capital, generally supports product development and marketing efforts, including market research. This is the first stage at which VC funds usually invest.

choices.itemBody: C. transformation of an idea into a business plan.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Stroh-03
entry.itemBody: Consider a put option selling for $4 in which the exercise price is $58. What is the profit for a put buyer if the price of the underlying at expiration is $57?

answerFeedback.5945437d-83cc-43b3-950f-b6ffd5bf6edf: Incorrect because this is the put's value at expiration. The put’s value at expiration = pT = Max(ST  – 0,X), where pT is the value of the put at expiration, X is the exercise price, and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. In this case, Max(0,58 – 57) = $1.
answerFeedback.abbfd7a9-2a5b-4144-aa6f-34a95d9fb55e: Correct because the put’s value at expiration = pT = Max(0,X – ST), where pT is the value of the put at expiration, X is the exercise price, and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. In this case, Max(0,58 – 57) = $1. The put buyer’s profit = Π = pT – p0 (where p0 is the price of the put at time 0) = 1 – 4 = –$3.
answerFeedback.f4b3fb9c-fcf2-4725-ad71-163ab91d7fd8: Incorrect because this is the put seller's profit. The put’s value at expiration = –pT = –Max(0,X – ST), where pT is the value of the put at expiration, X is the exercise price, and ST is the price of the underlying at expiration. In this case, –Max(0,58 – 57) = –$1. The put seller’s profit = Π = –pT + p0 (where p0 is the price of the put at time 0) = –1 + 4 = $3.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-PM-Glover-07
entry.itemBody: Base-rate neglect is a type of:

answerFeedback.2b5d079c-5b16-4f23-bbf3-9f333701351a: Correct because base-rate neglect and sample-size neglect are two types of representativeness bias that apply to FMPs (financial market participants). In base-rate neglect, a phenomenon's rate of incidence in a larger population—its base rate—is neglected in favor of specific information.
answerFeedback.979e7263-a1fc-46aa-86b4-72749e2658f8: Incorrect because base-rate neglect is a representativeness bias, not a hindsight bias. Hindsight bias refers to believing past events as having been predictable and reasonable to expect.
answerFeedback.b1444818-4552-47e0-9513-443f083c929a: Incorrect because base-rate neglect is a representativeness bias, not an endowment bias. Endowment bias is an emotional bias in which people value an asset more when they own it than when they do not.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Erickson-08
entry.itemBody: A mechanism that allows a hedge fund to temporarily restrict redemptions by all investors is known as a:

answerFeedback.25a32fae-c88d-4515-a8fd-ba832260c279: Incorrect because notice periods provide an opportunity for the hedge fund manager to liquidate a position in an orderly fashion without magnifying the losses. A notice period applies to all investors wanting to withdraw some or all of their capital from a hedge fund with the goal of providing the manager with advance warning of the withdrawal.
answerFeedback.620a4380-ed6b-4bc7-a865-4011ea6be83b: Incorrect because lockup periods—time periods when investors cannot withdraw their capital—provide the hedge fund manager the required time to implement and potentially realize a strategy’s expected results. Lockup periods apply to new investors in a hedge fund with the goal of allowing the hedge fund manager time to implement the fund's investment strategy.
answerFeedback.83667df2-2ead-40d9-b3a4-bcd4f7eda41b: Correct because in addition, funds sometimes impose a gate, which limits or restricts redemptions for a period of time. A gate is imposed by the hedge fund manager independent of any lockup period that may apply. A gate therefore applies to all investors for a finite period of time while a lockup period applies to new investors only.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Hambusch-05
entry.itemBody:
The partnership agreement of a private equity fund has no catch-up clause and includes the following:

Hurdle rate 9.0%
Performance fee 20.0%

Profits generated by the fund are allocated between limited partners and the general partner according to an 80/20 split. If the general partner has achieved an IRR of 22.0% for an investment, the general partner's return from the performance fee is closest to:

answerFeedback.ae2ce05b-7892-409c-a5e5-9f6a289b1af7: Correct because without a catch-up clause, the LPs will receive the entirety of the first 9% profit (up to the hurdle rate). The remaining 13% will be split 80/20 between the LPs and GP, reducing the GP’s return to 2,6%, based on the following formula: (IRR - hurdle rate) x performance fee = (22% – 9%) x 20% = 2.6%.
answerFeedback.b8a00a54-1103-4e69-bf27-fe9b6773f5fe: Incorrect because this answer choice is simply the product of the hurdle rate and the performance fee or 0.09 x 0.20 = 0.018 = 1.8%.
answerFeedback.d0ec7073-a962-42a3-9f1d-635e5a8e2a4e: Incorrect because this is the profit earned by the GP with, not without, a catch up clause. With a catch up clause, the LPs earn the first 9% (up to the hurdle rate) and the GP earns their 20% performance fee on the remaining 13% before any split = 13% x 20% = 2.2%. Remaining profits are then split 80/20. The GP receives (22% – 9% – 2.2%) x 20% = 2.16%. The GP's return = 2.2% + 2.16% = 4.36% ≈ 4.4%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-19
entry.itemBody: If a floating-rate note is trading at a discount to par, this bond's required margin is:

answerFeedback.1fe4b331-5796-4aee-bfa2-dd75003bb7b1: Incorrect because if the required margin is less than the quoted margin, the note will trade at a premium to par.
answerFeedback.75c76b63-6872-44b9-a3ad-7378351a5364: Incorrect because if the required margin is the same as the quoted margin, the note would trade at par value.
answerFeedback.764ddac5-7d35-43b0-9359-bb60658b25eb: Correct because if the required margin is greater than the quoted margin, the note will trade at a discount to par. For example on a floater with a margin of 50 bps, if the required margin goes up to 75 bps because of a downgrade in the issuer’s credit rating, a floater having a quoted margin of 50 bps now pays its investors a “deficient” interest payment. This FRN will be priced at a discount below par value.

choices.itemBody: B. the same as the quoted margin.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Equity 02DJE 14U1
entry.itemBody: A characteristic of real assets is that they most likely:

answerFeedback.1d6d41ff-33ae-4e2c-80f3-2ddeae684c09: Incorrect because real assets tend to trade in very illiquid markets.
answerFeedback.7a3a4dc7-51f3-4ee9-a36a-415f8c2a38b2: Correct because real assets are unique properties in the sense that no two properties are alike.
answerFeedback.fca1c18a-fa32-468c-b78e-34db63369b4b: Incorrect because investments in real assets generally require substantial management to ensure that the assets are maintained and used efficiently. Investment managers investing in such assets must either hire personnel to manage them or hire outside management companies. Either way, management of real assets is quite costly.

choices.itemBody: C. are unique assets with different attributes.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06998
entry.itemBody: A repo is best defined as a:

answerFeedback.037137ad-3ec5-4101-8658-968c45064eee: Incorrect because this describes a putable bond, not a repo transaction. A putable bond allows the investor to sell the bond back to the issuer prior to maturity, usually at par value.
answerFeedback.d30e10b9-f464-4e09-98d9-d7e984fd76df: Incorrect because a repurchase agreement or repo is the sale of a security with a simultaneous agreement by the seller to buy the same security back from the purchaser at an agreed-on price and future date. It is a private transaction between parties and not publicly-traded.
answerFeedback.eddd0bf2-a8ad-4aa3-935d-955f0acbdd69: Correct because a repurchase agreement or repo is the sale of a security with a simultaneous agreement by the seller to buy the same security back from the purchaser at an agreed-on price and future date.

choices.itemBody: B. security that provides the holder the right to sell it back to the issuer at par.
C. sale of a security with an agreement by the seller to buy it back at a specified price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Augulyte-01
entry.itemBody: Compared to mutual funds, hedge funds most likely:

answerFeedback.62724c40-fb55-426f-b4b6-a248be2ae5c5: Incorrect because with reduced operating constraints, hedge funds may invest in less liquid and unnoticed opportunities, the true valuation of which may at times be opaque.
answerFeedback.98a9d4e6-c265-4c60-8021-d595f13e3c41: Incorrect because a contemporary hedge fund generally has a goal to generate high returns, either in an absolute sense or on a risk-adjusted basis relative to its portfolio-level volatility. Gauging performance relative to a traditional index benchmark can be difficult, given that low correlation with traditional asset investing is frequently a selling point.
answerFeedback.a72e36f0-a272-4068-85dc-90d4955a8f55: Correct because investors in modern hedge funds are subject to extended holding periods (known as lockup periods) and subsequent notice periods before an investment redemption is possible. Compared, for example, to many mutual funds allowing easier redemption and guaranteed liquidity on one day’s notice, such mandatory periods combine with a lighter regulatory compliance burden (in certain areas) to allow hedge funds more flexibility.

choices.itemBody: B. have a longer notice period for redemptions than a mutual fund.
C. use a traditional index benchmark to gauge investment performance.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08721
entry.itemBody: A company announces an unexpected improvement in its earnings forecast for the coming year. The announcement most likely immediately impacts:

answerFeedback.8c0be039-a508-4951-a051-997e4730c7fa: Incorrect because book value reflects the difference between a company's total assets and total liabilities and not expectations regarding future earnings. The book value of a company's equity reflects the historical operating and financing decisions of its management.
answerFeedback.93af7b0e-830f-49c7-b2aa-85d10cd6db7b: Incorrect because book value reflects the difference between the company's total assets and total liabilities and not expectations regarding future earnings. The book value of a company's equity reflects the historical operating and financing decisions of its management. The market value of the company's equity reflects these decisions as well as investors' collective assessment and expectations about the company's future cash flows generated by its positive net present value investment opportunities.
answerFeedback.d7429128-50a5-4d35-9b6b-219fc3faec2d: Correct because market value reflects the collective and differing expectations of investors concerning the amount, timing, and uncertainty of the company's future cash flows, and an unexpected change in a company's earnings forecast will change investors expectations.

choices.itemBody: A. the company's book value of equity only.
B. the company's market value of equity only.
C. both the company's book value of equity and the company's market value of equity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Tomter-08
entry.itemBody: Which of the following sections of an IPS most likely provides information about specific types of assets to be excluded from a portfolio?

answerFeedback.02408adc-e963-4d46-ad21-9d04d4002cf2: Correct because the Investment Guidelines section provides information about how policy should be executed (e.g., on the permissible use of leverage and derivatives) and on specific types of assets excluded from investment, if any.
answerFeedback.7991c31e-cde4-47c5-963f-d8d06dab151b: Incorrect because the Procedures section explains the steps to take to keep the IPS current and the procedures to follow to respond to various contingencies.
answerFeedback.d7709420-9b73-4914-8920-dd3f2f0fce97: Incorrect because the Statement of Duties and Responsibilities section details the duties and responsibilities of the client, the custodian of the client’s assets, and the investment managers.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06982
entry.itemBody: Only the seller can default on a(n):

answerFeedback.0f703ce6-3444-4421-847b-75be6ea54e31: Incorrect because in contrast to forwards and swaps, in which either party could default to the other, default in options is possible only from the short to the long. Since a swap is equivalent to a series of forward contracts, default in swaps can occur from the long to the short and from the short to the long.
answerFeedback.6733d28c-62c3-4627-9839-f0ec82f37a0f: Incorrect because in contrast to forwards and swaps, in which either party could default to the other, default in options is possible only from the short to the long. Therefore, default in forwards can occur from the long to the short and from the short to the long.
answerFeedback.97b0395d-872c-4721-ab20-7cba5da2bfb7: Correct because the option buyer (the long) does not have to exercise the option, beyond the initial payment of the premium, therefore there is no obligation of the long to the short. Thus, only the short can default, which would occur if the long exercises the option and the short fails to do what it is supposed to do. Thus, in contrast to forwards and swaps, in which either party could default to the other, default in options is possible only from the short to the long.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Kennan-06
entry.itemBody:
Which of the following statements regarding alternative asset co-investing is correct?

• Statement 1: The investor invests in assets indirectly through a fund.

• Statement 2: The investor possesses rights to invest directly in the same assets

answerFeedback.5292418f-8e4c-4679-b0cd-f247ef7b1b85: Correct because both statements are correct. In co-investing, an investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund and has rights to invest in the same assets directly without an intermediary. Many investors gain direct investing experience via co-investing, where the investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund but also possesses rights (known as co-investment rights) to invest directly in the same assets. Direct investing occurs when an investor makes a direct investment in an asset without the use of an intermediary.
answerFeedback.9d270b96-07df-4ead-96c2-0245c48f9372: Incorrect because both statements are correct. In co-investing, an investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund and has rights to invest in the same assets directly without an intermediary. Many investors gain direct investing experience via co-investing, where the investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund but also possesses rights (known as co-investment rights) to invest directly in the same assets. Direct investing occurs when an investor makes a direct investment in an asset without the use of an intermediary.
answerFeedback.e9234126-8621-4fd8-bf3c-09f7904c6673: Incorrect because both statements are correct. In co-investing, an investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund and has rights to invest in the same assets directly without an intermediary. Many investors gain direct investing experience via co-investing, where the investor invests in assets indirectly through the fund but also possesses rights (known as co-investment rights) to invest directly in the same assets. Direct investing occurs when an investor makes a direct investment in an asset without the use of an intermediary.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Moustra-25
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in $ millions) about two companies for the year just ended:

  Company X Company Y
Operating income 10 12
Depreciation and amortization 2 1
Interest expense 1 3
Debt 50 60

Based on an assessment of leverage, Company X has:

answerFeedback.25a63fb4-6580-4b9f-adf2-ac0fdec7a299: Incorrect because Company X has higher, not lower, creditworthiness than Company Y. The candidate in this case subtracts instead of adding back depreciation and amortization to calculate EBITDA, and calculates EBITDA for Company X as EBITDA = 10 – 2 = 8 and its leverage ratio as Debt/EBITDA = 50/8 = 6.25. For Company Y, the candidate calculates EBITDA as EBITDA = 12 – 1 = 11 and its leverage ratio as Debt/EBITDA = 60/11 ≈ 5.4545 ≈ 5.45, indicating incorrectly that Company X has a higher leverage ratio and thus lower creditworthiness than Company Y.
answerFeedback.65874745-9aba-45d3-96af-7d92c6f7229d: Correct because Company X's EBITDA is calculated as EBITDA = operating income + depreciation + amortization = 10 + 2 = 12 and Debt/EBITDA = 50/12 ≈ 4.1667 ≈ 4.2. Company Y's EBITDA is calculated as EBITDA = 12 + 1 = 13 and Debt/EBITDA = 60/13 ≈ 4.6154 ≈ 4.6. Company X has a lower leverage ratio, and thus higher creditworthiness than Company Y.
answerFeedback.ffd83fee-41d6-4302-a761-1f46bfa5c7cc: Incorrect because Company X has higher creditworthiness than Company Y. The candidate in this case omits to add back depreciation and amortization to calculate EBITDA, and calculates the leverage ratio for Company X as Debt/EBIT = 50/10 = 5 and the leverage ratio for Company Y as Debt/EBIT = 60/12 = 5, indicating incorrectly that the two companies have the same creditworthiness.

choices.itemBody: B. the same creditworthiness as Company Y.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07237
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company for its fiscal year:

Net profit margin 8%
Total asset turnover 1.5
Financial leverage 1.2
EPS €0.15
Dividend per common share €0.10

The sustainable growth rate is closest to:

answerFeedback.184d058e-8ffa-4528-95ec-f3f17a405d03: Incorrect because it assumes that ROE = net profit margin × leverage (omitting asset turnover); or = 8% × 1.2 = 0.096. Substituting into the sustainable growth rate = retention rate × ROE = (1 – 0.10/0.15) × 0.096 = 0.0320 = 3.2%.
answerFeedback.2e89aa9a-1802-44d0-ae63-19d7b7724ba1: Incorrect because it uses the payout ratio, not retention rate, when calculating the sustainable growth rate (sustainable growth rate = retention rate × ROE). Based on DuPont analysis (ROE = net profit margin × total asset turnover × leverage), ROE = 8% × 1.2 × 1.5, or 0.144; multiplying by the payout ratio = 0.144 × (0.10 / 0.15) = 0.096 = 9.6%.
answerFeedback.45b8393a-f3c2-4894-bf31-0524447ad933: Correct because the sustainable growth rate = retention rate × ROE, where retention rate = (1 – payout ratio), and the payout ratio is the percentage of earnings that the company pays out as dividends to shareholders, or (EPS – DPS) / EPS, and using the DuPont analysis ROE = net profit margin × total asset turnover × leverage. The retention rate = 1 – (0.10 / 0.15) = 1 – 0.667 = 0.3333. ROE = 8% × 1.5 × 1.2 = 0.144. Substituting into the sustainable growth rate formula: 0.3333 × 0.144 = 0.04799 ≈ 4.8%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516135
entry.itemBody: An increase in the dividend payout ratio will most likely increase the intrinsic value when using a(n):

answerFeedback.790733cf-2bab-45c5-af19-725f9c84a099: Correct because an increase in the dividend payout ratio will increase the cash expected to be distributed to shareholders. The dividend discount model is the present value of the cash expected to be distributed to shareholders. Therefore an increase in the dividend payout ratio will increase the intrinsic value in a present value model.
answerFeedback.972adb1f-d342-4393-971c-ac3be4974fd9: Incorrect because the increase in earnings affects the multiplier models, but the increase in the dividend payout ratio does not have any effect.
answerFeedback.fcb7d7e9-246f-43bf-8bae-7cce0dcf408d: Incorrect because the increase in the dividend payout ratio does not have an effect on the asset-based valuation model.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606004
entry.itemBody: If Investor 1 has a lower risk aversion coefficient than Investor 2, will Investor 2's optimal portfolio have a higher expected return on the capital allocation line?

answerFeedback.3bccc24b-b8f6-4328-be2b-1ad7f3427d6d: Incorrect because Investor 2 has a higher risk aversion coefficient, which means a lower risk tolerance and a lower expected return on the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.aefd933e-a773-4c44-8bc9-3eb89bfca1fa: Incorrect because Investor 2 has a higher risk aversion coefficient, which means a lower risk tolerance and a lower expected return on the capital allocation line.
answerFeedback.e83c52b2-bfd2-4943-b024-d09464a38716: Correct because Investor 2 has a higher risk aversion coefficient, which means a lower risk tolerance and a lower expected return on the capital allocation line.

choices.itemBody: B. No because Investor 2 has a lower risk tolerance
C. No because Investor 2 has a higher risk tolerance

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07170
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a company's earnings:

Retention rate 40%
Growth rate 1%

According to the Gordon growth model, if an investor's required return is 6%, the justified forward P/E is:

answerFeedback.2f78d28b-389f-4c15-9529-16d0661ed3d6: Incorrect but is the result when the retention rate is substituted for the payout rate: 0.4/(0.06 – 0.01) = 0.4/0.05 = 8.
answerFeedback.6ce40f51-cc0d-492f-b6ba-8087c97abd98:
Correct because the dividend payout ratio = (1 ‒ earnings retention rate) = (1 – 0.40) = 0.6. The justified forward P/E is:

p/(r – g) where p = dividend payout ratio, r = required rate of return and g = sustainable growth rate, therefore P/E = 0.6/ (0.06 – 0.01) = 0.6/0.05 = 12.
answerFeedback.ba9ef26b-3b9a-4b4c-8de7-c9336c0d78be: Incorrect because the growth rate is omitted: 0.6/(0.06) = 10.

entry.title: ITEM_20170427023
entry.itemBody: A hedge fund begins the year with $120 million and earns a 25% return for the year. The fund charges a 1.5% management fee on end-of-year fund value and a 15% incentive fee on the return, net of the management fees, that is in excess of a 6% fixed hurdle rate. The fund’s investors’ return for the year, net of fees, is closest to:

answerFeedback.72622ea6-7182-4e0a-b06e-7b82a6e338d4:
Incorrect because it ignores that management fee. The fund grows to $150 million.

Incentive fee is ($150 million – $120 million) × 0.15 = $4.5 million

$150 million – $120 million – $4.5 million = $25.5 million

$25.5 million/$120 million = 0.2125
answerFeedback.8a1c836d-707f-4fac-a550-663d0fa4fef9: Incorrect because it fails to adjust for the hurdle rate when calculating the incentive fee or 0.15 × $27.75 million = $4.1625 million and $27.75 million – $4.1625 million = $23.5875 million. $23.5875 million/$120 million = 19.66%.
answerFeedback.e6d53523-fdb4-4350-907c-aac084c0ad70:
Correct because the $120 million grows by 25% to $150 million [= $120 million × (1 + 0.25)]. The management fee is $2.25 million (= $150 million × 0.015), leaving $147.75 million, net of the management fee, or an increase of $27.75 million over the beginning value of $120 million. The 6% hurdle rate requires an increase of $7.2 million (= $120 million × 0.06), so the fund has earned $20.55 million (= $27.75 million – $7.2 million) over the hurdle rate, net of the management fee.

The incentive fee is 15% of this, or $3.0825 million (= $20.55 million × 0.015), leaving an increase in fund assets, net of management and incentive fees, of $24.6675 million (= $27.75 million – $3.0825 million). The investors’ return, net of fees, is $24.6675/$120 million = 20.56%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03632
entry.itemBody: All else being equal, which of the following bonds most likely has the highest yield to maturity?

answerFeedback.2b701c05-c8f2-4d97-8751-563738d0a89b: Incorrect because a put provision gives the bondholders the right to sell the bond back to the issuer at a pre-determined price on specified dates. Because a put provision has value to the bondholders, the price of a putable bond will be higher than the price of an otherwise similar bond issued without the put provision. Similarly, the yield on a bond with a put provision will be lower than the yield on an otherwise similar non-putable bond.
answerFeedback.5733382e-bb85-4638-b6a8-347a68fbe512: Incorrect because from the investor's perspective, a convertible bond offers several advantages relative to a non-convertible bond. Because the conversion provision is valuable to bondholders, the price of a convertible bond is higher than the price of an otherwise similar bond without the conversion provision. Similarly, the yield on a convertible bond is lower than the yield on an otherwise similar non-convertible bond.
answerFeedback.78ab7714-d7c5-42c0-99d5-b4daba33446b: Correct because bonds with contingent write-down provisions are convertible on the downside. In the case of contingent convertible bonds (CoCos), conversion is automatic if a specified event occurs.  In such cases, the CoCos immediately convert into equity. Because the conversion is not at the option of the bondholders but automatic, CoCos force bondholders to take losses. For this reason, CoCos must offer a higher yield than otherwise similar bonds.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516014
entry.itemBody: According to behavioral finance, observed overreaction in securities markets most likely occurs because of:

answerFeedback.0ce5a9d1-378f-4e12-8a2c-7c696a987c40: Incorrect because the disposition effect is a behavioral bias in which investors tend to avoid realizing losses but rather seek to realize gains.
answerFeedback.a2cbb20f-94af-4ee6-a19c-b088918872af: Correct because according to loss aversion–related arguments in behavioral theories, investors dislike losses more than they like comparable gains. Thus, such a behavioral bias can explain observed overreaction in markets.
answerFeedback.fe92299c-0611-4216-8d99-37693a520821: Incorrect because gambler’s fallacy is a behavioral bias in which recent outcomes affect investors’ estimates of future probabilities.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601008
entry.itemBody: Using put–call parity, a long call can best be replicated by going:

answerFeedback.81bec91d-7389-4015-a4e6-a5ea12321988: Incorrect because the short asset position must be a long position, and the long bond position must be a short position. According to put–call parity, a long call is equal to long put, long asset, short bond.
answerFeedback.f3a8156c-8886-4f76-8653-5a5bb7a99353: Correct because according to put–call parity, a long call is equal to long put, long asset, short bond.
answerFeedback.f9febe4f-61c1-4c1c-8ede-7321093676d5: Incorrect because the short put position must be a long position. According to put–call parity, a long call is equal to long put, long asset, short bond.

choices.itemBody: A. long the put, short the asset, and long the bond.
B. short the put, long the asset, and short the bond.
C. long the put, long the asset, and short the bond.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B Deriv 08HXE
entry.itemBody: The value of a European call option is inversely related:

answerFeedback.1735696d-ff70-4215-b551-3d83b8043342: Incorrect because as described in the response rationale for the correct answer, the value of a European call option is inversely related to only the dividends paid by the underlying stock.
answerFeedback.7260fcb7-ecc8-4290-8094-b4fb34f3c115: Correct because a European call option is worth less the more benefits that are paid by the underlying and worth more the more costs that are incurred in holding the underlying. Dividends are benefits paid by the underlying. So, a European call must be worth less when the underlying pays dividend than when it does not. Therefore, dividends paid by the underlying is inversely related to the value of a European call option.
answerFeedback.e61c67a9-8fe3-4097-80db-1acd89f491a8: Incorrect because the value of a European call is directly related to the risk-free interest rate. It is therefore not inversely related to the risk-free interest rate.

choices.itemBody: A. only to the risk-free interest rate.
B. only to the dividends paid by the underlying stock.
C. both to the risk-free interest rate and to the dividends paid by the underlying stock.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Equity-Young-16
entry.itemBody: With respect to index construction, which method of grouping companies most likely experiences the highest turnover in its constituents? Grouping by:

answerFeedback.6fed66b2-cd39-4e11-bc22-5d958367bade: Incorrect because company groupings based on statistical similarities tend to have greater constituent turnover than those based on industries or countries. These groupings are usually relative (e.g., companies with dividend yields at or above the 75th percentile as of the measurement date) and tend to show far more turnover in their constituents than groupings based on industries and countries, because these statistics are less stable by company and companies’ rankings change.
answerFeedback.823d9510-4cfc-44e0-8978-d9ba56bc69ab: Correct because company groupings based on statistical similarities tend to have greater constituent turnover than those based on industries or countries. These groupings are usually relative (e.g., companies with dividend yields at or above the 75th percentile as of the measurement date) and tend to show far more turnover in their constituents than groupings based on industries and countries, because these statistics are less stable by company and companies’ rankings change.
answerFeedback.9f3a11ea-5338-494c-ad6e-c9e575544a5f: Incorrect because company groupings based on statistical similarities tend to have greater constituent turnover than those based on industries or countries. These groupings are usually relative (e.g., companies with dividend yields at or above the 75th percentile as of the measurement date) and tend to show far more turnover in their constituents than groupings based on industries and countries, because these statistics are less stable by company and companies’ rankings change.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2023.01-Alt-Hung-01
entry.itemBody: Unlike traditional financial assets, digital assets are most likely:

answerFeedback.714b4aeb-8f9d-4b1b-8a8f-c399d557b701: Correct because most digital assets do not have an inherent value based on underlying assets or on the potential cash flow—interest and dividends—they can or are expected to generate. They derive their price solely from an anticipated asset appreciation from a perceived scarcity value (due to limitations on the total supply of currency) and the potential ability to transfer value in the future (due to unique features in the underlying algorithms that may facilitate certain types of financial transactions).
answerFeedback.7a73b6db-86b0-43d5-ac06-684ae35b27cb: Incorrect because traditional assets are generally recorded in private ledgers maintained by central intermediaries. The ownership and exchange of digital assets are generally recorded on a decentralized digital ledger using cryptography and enhanced algorithms.
answerFeedback.ff5d33e3-af37-4a40-8d97-f173e6b85193: Incorrect because legal and regulatory standards for traditional financial instruments and assets and trading in these are well developed and are often comparable across national borders; this is not the case with digital assets. Comprehensive rules that are specific to digital assets—their formation, trading, and legal standards—are still being developed.

choices.itemBody: B. recorded in private ledgers maintained by central intermediaries.
C. valued based on anticipated price appreciation rather than underlying cash flow.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Deriv-Simsek-05
entry.itemBody: Which of the following transactions most likely represents a fair value hedge?

answerFeedback.1e712436-13ff-4381-bf09-c6663806a2f7: Incorrect because it is an example of a cash flow hedge. Derivatives designated as absorbing the variable cash flow of a floating-rate asset or liability such as foreign exchange, interest rates, or commodities are referred to as cash flow hedges. For instance, the FX forward to hedge forecasted sales constitutes an example of a cash flow hedge.
answerFeedback.2304e3f6-7214-48e4-b90c-2be7fb93db9c: Incorrect because it is an example of a cash flow hedge. Derivatives designated as absorbing the variable cash flow of a floating-rate asset or liability such as foreign exchange, interest rates, or commodities are referred to as cash flow hedges. A swap to a fixed rate for a floating-rate debt liability is another example of a cash flow hedge.
answerFeedback.31f7ac1b-4553-4f12-998d-f374c37821f4: Correct because it is an example of a fair value hedge. A fair value hedge designation applies when a derivative is deemed to offset the fluctuation in fair value of an asset or liability. For example, a commodities producer might sell its inventory forward in anticipation of lower future prices.

choices.itemBody: B. Currency forward to hedge forecasted sales
C. Interest rate swap to a fixed rate for floating-rate debt

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Equity-Chan-03
entry.itemBody: If the current share price is $60, a trader who wants to purchase the share at $58 or less will most likely place a:

answerFeedback.15226491-833a-4f37-9dbc-938f1fbbb0f1: Correct because a limit order conveys almost the same instruction as market order: Obtain the best price immediately available, but in no event accept a price higher than a specified limit price when buying or accept a price lower than a specified limit price when selling.
answerFeedback.2b1b0fc7-8703-4f38-9aa8-35782f921882: Incorrect because a market order instructs the broker or exchange to obtain the best price immediately available when filling the order. The trader might purchase it at more than $58 by using market order.
answerFeedback.57769282-b02e-4b4a-823b-8abe30cbe0ab: Incorrect because a stop-buy order is to buy at a price specified above the market price. Because stop-sell orders become valid when prices are falling and stop-buy orders become valid when prices are rising.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01264
entry.itemBody: A lifecycle fund will most likely:

answerFeedback.059ea611-3ee4-4401-a1a0-c65d51e8990d: Correct because lifecycle or Target Date funds manage the asset mix based on a desired retirement date. For example, a Target Date fund 40 years into the future might be 90 percent invested in equities and 10 percent in fixed income. As time passes, however, the fund would gradually change the mix of shares from equity to fixed income.
answerFeedback.1e848ccf-a9d7-41f5-9f4c-55fc611d08d1: Incorrect because the asset allocation will change as described in the response rationale for the answer key, but will change due to target date, not due to market opportunities. Tactical asset allocation is a short-term change in allocation to capture market opportunities.
answerFeedback.d0691496-f405-483d-a827-289e1317e91a: Incorrect because the asset allocation would change as described in the response rationale for the answer key.

choices.itemBody: A. maintain a fixed asset allocation of stocks and bonds.
B. use tactical asset allocation to capture market opportunities.
C. change the asset allocation as the fund nears its target date.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-07782
entry.itemBody:
A trader enters into the following margin transaction:

Purchase price, per share €100
Initial margin posted as equity 45%
Holding period 1 year
Unleveraged security return during the period 15%
Call money rate, one year 4%

If there are no dividends or commissions, and interest on the margin loan is paid at the end of the period, the trader's rate of return on the margin transaction is closest to:

answerFeedback.65914731-3972-46a6-a3c2-5f79a3accb53: Correct because the initial margin requirement is the minimum fraction of the purchase price that must be trader's equity. With the purchase price = $100, initial investment = purchase price × initial margin requirement = €100 × 45% = €45.00; trading gains/losses = purchase price × unleveraged security return = €100 × 15% = €15.00; margin interest paid = purchase price × (1−initial margin requirement) × call money rate = $100 × (1−45%) × 4% = €2.20. Remaining equity = initial investment + trading gains/losses – margin interest paid. Substituting, remaining equity = €45.00 + €15.00 − €2.20 = €57.80. Rate of return = (remaining equity − initial investment) / initial investment. Substituting, rate of return = (€57.80 − €45.00) / €45.00 = 0.2844 or 28.4%.
answerFeedback.748bd9f1-bbd8-4bf6-b575-3d7a932e1c0b: Incorrect because margin interest paid is calculated based on the initial investment. Margin interest paid = initial investment × call money rate = €45.00 × 4% = €1.80. Remaining equity = €45.00 + €15.00 − €1.80 = €58.20. Rate of return = (€58.20 − €45.00) / €45.00 = 0.2933 ≈ 29.3%.
answerFeedback.b3f659de-797a-409a-8b22-d689a7a495e3: Incorrect because it is the unleveraged return divided by 1 – the margin requirement = 0.15 / (1 – 0.45) = 0.2727 ≈ 27.3%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04301
entry.itemBody: In which form of market efficiency do security prices fully reflect private information?

answerFeedback.30d82eb5-cba8-41c5-bcaa-f5d58d5b407f: Incorrect because weak-form efficiency makes no claims about prices reflecting private information, only that prices reflect all past market data such as price and volume information.
answerFeedback.53b5d46f-f711-438c-bc59-baa616c71dc5: Incorrect because semi-strong form efficiency makes no claims on prices reflecting private information, only that prices reflect all past market data such as price and volume information and all publicly known information such as financial statements.
answerFeedback.ecc78b8f-8cd2-4e20-8e3f-3b1a7433f42e: Correct because in a strong-form efficient market, security prices fully reflect private information.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516077
entry.itemBody:
The data for two stocks in an index are as follows:

Stock Shares Outstanding Percent of Shares in Market Float Beginning of Period Price ($) End of Period Price ($) Dividends per Share ($)
A 5,000 90 40 45 1.00
B 2,000 100 68 60 0.50
Assuming the beginning value of the float-adjusted market-capitalization-weighted equity index is 100, the ending value is closest to:

answerFeedback.6f07f985-b290-4604-a93f-1ddcdf81148f:
Incorrect. It does make adjustment for the market float but makes the mistake of including dividends in the ending price of the stock.

Stock Shares Outstanding % Shares in Market Float Shares in Index Beginning of Period Price ($) Beg. Float Adj. Market Cap ($) End of Period Price + Dividend ($) Ending Float Adj. Market Cap ($)
A 5,000 90 4,500 40 180,000 46 207,000
B 2,000 100 2,000 68 136,000 60.5 121,000
Total 316,000 328,000
Index value 100 103.80
answerFeedback.7daa5017-347f-4811-ac16-5c232ca780bb:
Incorrect. It ignores the float and simply computes the index on the basis of market-capitalization weighting.

Stock Shares Outstanding Beginning of Period Price ($) Beg. Float Adj. Market Cap ($) End of Period Price ($) Ending Float Adj. Market Cap ($)
A 5,000 40 200,000 45 225,000
B 2,000 68 136,000 60 120,000
Total 336,000 345,000
Index value 100 102.68
answerFeedback.fb0674bb-2141-4fe2-a082-2646f147dc33:
Correct. In float-adjusted market-capitalization weighting, the weight on each constituent security is determined by adjusting its market capitalization for its market float. As the following computations show, the ending value of the index equals 102.06 (322,500/316,000).

Stock Shares Outstanding
(1)		 Percent of Shares in Market Float
(2)		 Shares in Index
(1 × 2 = 3)		 Beginning of Period Price ($)
(4)		 Beginning Float Adj. Market Cap ($)
(3 × 4 = 5)		 End of Period Price ($)
(6)		 Ending Float Adj. Market Cap ($)
(3 × 6)
A 5,000 90 4,500 40 180,000 45 202,500
B 2,000 100 2,000 68 136,000 60 120,000
Total 316,000 322,500
Index value 100 102.06

entry.title: ITEM_Copy of CFA-L1-07270
entry.itemBody: A trader sells a put option with an exercise price of $33.50 for $3.00. If the price of the underlying asset at expiration is $29.50, the trader's profit is:

answerFeedback.0444c1b8-6144-4c7f-bb13-e834dfb59746: Incorrect because it is the difference between the exercise price X and the price of the underlying asset at expiry ST, or $33.50 – $29.50 = $4.00, which is equal to the value of this in-the-money put at expiration for the put buyer. It is not equal to the profit for the put seller of –$1.00.
answerFeedback.71ee1cab-c924-45a5-9c9f-c2219ac16c77: Incorrect because $1.00 represents the profit to the buyer of the put option, not the profit to the seller. The profit to the put buyer" is Π = Max(0,X – ST) – p0, where Π is the profit, X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying asset at expiration, and p0 is the price of the put option at initiation or the purchase (or sale) price of the put option. Thus, the profit to the put buyer is Π = Max(0,$33.50 – $29.50) – $3.00 = $4.00 – $3.00 = $1.00.
answerFeedback.ec930a39-dc54-4e09-8e72-5451330dd613: Correct because the profit to the put seller is Π = –Max(0,X – ST) + p0, where Π is the profit, X is the exercise price, ST is the price of the underlying asset at expiration, and p0 is the price of the put option at initiation or the purchase (or sale) price of the put option. Thus, the profit is Π = –Max(0,$33.50 – $29.50) + $3.00 = –$4.00 + $3.00 = –$1.00.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607073
entry.itemBody: A bond has a 10-year maturity, a $1,000 face value, and a 7% coupon rate. If the market requires a yield of 8% on similar bonds, it will most likely trade at a:

answerFeedback.be57e474-33fd-403c-aba3-7ced499b48eb: Correct because when the required yield is higher than the coupon rate, the bond will trade at a discount to par.
answerFeedback.d1425a3f-987d-4a59-bf5a-1b8c65744e15: Incorrect because a bond trades at a discount when the required yield is higher than the coupon rate.
answerFeedback.defd8163-d9c5-40ad-9df8-cd088c32d1ca: Incorrect because a bond trades at a premium when the required yield is less than the coupon rate.

choices.itemBody: C. discount or premium, depending on its duration.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03852
entry.itemBody: A bond has an annual modified duration of 8 and an annual convexity measure of 150. If the bond's yield to maturity decreases by 140 bps, the change in the price of this bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.120b61c1-4373-46f3-9e8c-b9f8baa34cdd:
Correct because:

Expected price change = (− AnnModDur × Δyield) + [0.5 × AnnConvexity × (Δyield)2] =

[ − 8 × (− 0.0140)] + [0.5 × (150) × (− 0.0140)2] = 0.112 + 0.0147 = 0.1267 = 12.7%.
answerFeedback.6a596356-86d4-453d-80f2-5d0736771a2b:
Incorrect because “0.5” is omitted from the second term of calculation: Expected price ∆ ≠

[− 8 × (− 0.0140)] + [(150) × (− 0.0140)2] = 0.112 + 0.0294 = 0.1414 = 14.1%.
answerFeedback.a91c8b67-87b7-40bf-8464-b6af74cbaa9b:
Incorrect because the second term is subtracted instead of added: Expected price ∆ ≠

[− 8 × (− 0.0140)] − [0.5 × (150) × (− 0.0140)2] = 0.112 − 0.0147 = 0.0973 = 9.7%.

entry.title: ITEM_20170601049
entry.itemBody: At expiration, an option that is in the money will most likely have:

answerFeedback.112a720e-678e-4f58-a2a7-8e90cf439b79: Correct. At expiration, options have no time value; if they are in the money, they have exercise value.
answerFeedback.397c842e-dfe9-4556-864a-ff110831f8e4: Incorrect. At expiration, options have no time value.
answerFeedback.6e3b3cad-ba4d-491d-8546-c3905fd889ed: Incorrect. At expiration, options have no time value.

choices.itemBody: A. time value, but no exercise value.
B. exercise value, but no time value.
C. both time value and exercise value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.03-Alt-Loo-21
entry.itemBody: Investing in an existing solar power plant is most appropriately categorized as a:

answerFeedback.223a6847-2277-44e8-aa72-f2014edf565f: Incorrect because a newly constructed solar power plant is a brownfield investment instead of a greenfield investment. Infrastructure investments may also be categorized by the underlying asset’s stage of development. Greenfield investments are defined as developing new assets and new infrastructure. By contrast, brownfield investments expand existing facilities and may involve privatization of public assets or a sale leaseback of completed greenfield projects.
answerFeedback.86466418-c11b-405c-8ffb-f94c69f418b9: Incorrect because a newly constructed solar power plant is a utility asset instead of a social infrastructure asset. Social infrastructure investments are directed toward human activities and include such assets as educational, health care, social housing, and correctional facilities, with the focus on providing, operating, and maintaining the asset infrastructure.
answerFeedback.ad5a357f-571f-4369-808c-198159895aaa: Correct because utility investments encompass environmentally sustainable development, with an increasing focus on renewable technologies, including solar, wind, and waste-to-energy power generation.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05116
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three companies and their common shares:

Company 1 Company 2 Company 3
Next year's expected dividend (D1) $1.00 $1.00 $1.25
Dividend payout ratio 10% 20% 15%

All three companies have the same ROE of 10% and required return of 10%. Using the Gordon growth model, the company with the highest intrinsic value is:

answerFeedback.a53c5ab0-9361-439c-940e-ffb4da827a57:
Incorrect because the value of Company 3 is lower than that of Company 1 at $83.33 / share:

b = (1 – 0.15) = 0.85; g = 0.85 × 0.10 = 0.085

V = 1.25 / (0.10 – 0.085) = 1.25 / 0.015 ≈ $83.33. A candidate may also mistakenly choose this answer choice because it has the highest dividend.
answerFeedback.c19c7472-9285-4017-bc8a-3580b9c9d76a:
Incorrect because the value of Company 2 is lower than that of Company 1 at $50 / share:

b = (1 – 0.20) = 0.80; g = 0.80 × 0.10 = 0.08

V = 1.00 / (0.10 – 0.08) = 1.00 / 0.02 = $50.00. A candidate may also mistakenly choose this answer choice because it has the highest dividend payout ratio.
answerFeedback.d104460d-d329-47a6-bcd0-cb6879df95e6:
Correct because the estimated value (V0) for Company 1 is highest, at $100 / share:

V0 = D1÷(r-g)

Where: D1 = next year's expected dividend

r = required return

g = dividend growth rate

g = b × ROE

b = earnings retention rate = 1 – dividend payout ratio 

b = (1 – 0.10) = 0.90; g = 0.90 × 0.10 = 0.09

V = 1.00 / (0.10 – 0.09) = 1.00 / 0.01 = $100.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08120
entry.itemBody: With respect to the capital market line, the market portfolio is best described as the:

answerFeedback.0d5cb9db-7671-45e3-9829-a3cadb1e1555: Incorrect because the market portfolio is the optimal risky portfolio rather than a combination of the risk-free asset and a portfolio of risky assets. All combinations of the risk-free asset and a risky asset lie on the capital allocation line. Superimposing an investor's indifference curves on the capital allocation line will lead to the optimal investor portfolio. An investor's optimal portfolio could be any point on the CML.
answerFeedback.1509c3fd-0316-4e58-9a1f-670962ca8a89: Incorrect because an investor's optimal portfolio (the combination of the risk-free asset and the market portfolio that maximizes an individual investor's utility) could be any point on the CML. The location of an optimal investor portfolio (not the optimal risky portfolio) depends on the investor's risk preferences. A highly risk-averse investor may invest a large proportion, even 100 percent, of his/her assets in the risk-free asset. A less risk-averse investor, however, may invest a large portion of his/her wealth in the optimal risky asset.
answerFeedback.6a969de5-1263-4fba-a91f-7a713126819e: Correct because the specific capital allocation line that uses the market portfolio as the optimal risky portfolio is known as the capital market line (CML). Further, theoretically, the market includes all risky assets. Because the CML assumes homogeneous expectations, only one optimal (risky) portfolio exists.

choices.itemBody: B. portfolio that maximizes an investor's utility.
C. optimal combination of the risk-free asset and a portfolio of risky assets.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Hambusch-03
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate? In derivatives pricing:

answerFeedback.09609cfb-3cab-48a7-8e3c-202e02b81a9e: Incorrect because the derivative price is the price that guarantees the risk-free combination of the derivative and the underlying produces a risk-free return. Also, risk-neutral pricing uses the fact that arbitrage opportunities guarantee that a risk-free portfolio consisting of the underlying and the derivative must earn the risk-free rate, not a rate of return equal to the risk-free rate plus a risk premium.
answerFeedback.10ff5c3f-750c-4be9-ab3c-5a8646952a6c: Incorrect because the important point to understand is that while the risk aversion of investors is relevant to pricing assets, it is not relevant to pricing derivatives. As such, derivatives pricing is sometimes called risk-neutral pricing. Therefore, investors are not assumed to be risk averse.
answerFeedback.affb3874-e934-49f4-87cd-e0c375e51827: Correct because the risk aversion of the investor is not relevant to pricing the derivative, one can just as easily obtain the derivative price by assuming that the investor is risk neutral. That means that the expected payoff of the derivative can be discounted at the risk-free rate rather than the risk-free rate plus a risk premium.

choices.itemBody: A. investors are assumed to be risk averse.
B. expected payoffs of the derivative can be discounted at the risk-free rate.
C. a portfolio consisting of the underlying and the derivative must earn the risk-free rate plus a risk premium.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-01
entry.itemBody: An example of a negative bond covenant is a:

answerFeedback.0d461a01-e3af-4031-abfd-b67396d8fac8: Correct because examples of negative covenants include the Restrictions on debt regulate the issue of additional debt.
answerFeedback.49b1ac73-7a6f-43f3-bba8-22abbe971acc: Incorrect because affirmative covenants are typically administrative in nature and include a promise to comply with all laws and regulations, maintain its current lines of business, insure and maintain its assets, and pay taxes as they come due.
answerFeedback.8f6c04e4-1d61-4ebf-a2eb-e2ee602426cd: Incorrect because affirmative covenants are typically administrative in nature and include a promise to comply with all laws and regulations, maintain its current lines of business, insure and maintain its assets, and pay taxes as they come due.

choices.itemBody: B. limit on the issuance of additional debt.
C. requirement to comply with existing laws and regulations.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606078
entry.itemBody: The slope of the security market line is best derived from the:

answerFeedback.7196d50c-dfd6-43c7-974e-0493feecd0d1: Incorrect because the beta of the security is shown on the x-axis.
answerFeedback.947e8302-3947-479b-be1c-0f9b6d4a77df: Incorrect because the risk-free rate of return marks the intercept term of the security market line.
answerFeedback.f7fe6761-1a13-4349-ba92-eba8ce67055d: Correct because the security market line is a graphical representation of the CAPM with beta on the x-axis and expected return on the y-axis. The slope of the line is given by the market risk premium, the difference between the equity market return and the risk-free rate of interest.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Derivs-Agarwal-06
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements is most accurate?

answerFeedback.3de85467-227d-4cc8-95d2-22be3650d88c: Incorrect because the world of forwards, futures, and swaps, however, uses different terminology with respect to price and value. As the underlying moves, swap values become either positive or negative. The forward, futures, or swap price is a concept that represents the fixed price or rate at which the underlying will be purchased at a later date. The value and price are not at all comparable with each other. Therefore, the statement that the price and the value of a swap are the same is incorrect.
answerFeedback.69a15504-ed69-46f9-8bdc-e27bd9b666f1: Incorrect because it is the value of a swap contract that is zero at initiation and not the price. Forwards, futures, and swaps start off with values of zero.
answerFeedback.b88f3d16-f9a7-48d2-bba0-397a857ffb38: Correct because the value of a swap will fluctuate as market conditions change.

choices.itemBody: A. The value of a swap fluctuates as market conditions change
B. The price and the value of a swap are the same at expiration
C. The price of a swap at initiation is zero as there is no initial outlay of cash

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-03970
entry.itemBody: In a declining interest rate environment, an investor would find it most difficult to estimate future cash flows for which of the following bonds with similar maturities?

answerFeedback.aa85d031-39a7-47cf-95ca-6196554f33ea: Incorrect because even though coupon payments will decline as interest rates decline, the floor sets a minimum (and constant) level of payments when rates decline to and below the floor level. In this sense, forecasting cash flows is less difficult than for the pass-through security.
answerFeedback.bb2543e3-1c7c-4b94-97fe-ac95701bbd3f: Correct because when interest rates decline, borrowers will accelerate their prepayments. Compared to the floater with a floor, the mortgage pass-through has no restriction on the dollar amount of the prepayments. Prepayments are modeled to a benchmark but actual experience may be greater or less than forecast.
answerFeedback.d24d25cb-853e-467c-ae4f-e445dc72ff30: Incorrect because if interest rates decline, a putable bond will increase in value to a level above the put price and the bondholder will not put the bond to the issuer (long the option).

entry.title: ITEM_20190531024
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information on three investors. Each investor holds a bond with a Macaulay duration of 5.5 years in his portfolio:

  Investment Horizon
Investor A 5 years
Investor B 2 years
Investor C 8 years

All else equal, which investor is currently most vulnerable to an increase in interest rates?

answerFeedback.15eac657-ac0f-4cef-81f0-f73282d2f0f9: Correct because Investor B has an investment horizon shorter than the Macaulay duration of 5.5 years. When the investment horizon is shorter than the Macaulay duration of the bond, market price risk dominates coupon reinvestment risk. The investor is vulnerable to higher interest rates.
answerFeedback.ad9c663c-9a50-4399-8e73-a01f22f77324: Incorrect because Investor C has an investment horizon longer than the Macaulay duration. In this case, coupon reinvestment risk dominates market price risk. Also, assuming an interest rate increase, the gain from reinvesting coupon payments at a higher rate will outweigh any loss incurred from a drop in bond price.
answerFeedback.c0a7c707-10c1-4618-a0dc-131ea6ed6ae2: Incorrect because although Investor A has an investment horizon shorter than the Macaulay duration of 5.5 years, it is not substantially shorter. Also, he is not as vulnerable to an increase in rates as Investor B, whose bond has considerable market price risk.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516045
entry.itemBody: The sensitivity of a bond’s price to a change in the benchmark yield curve is best described as:

answerFeedback.11413804-5659-4a68-a0c6-2c07e023e278: Incorrect because the price value of a basis point is a type of yield duration (as opposed to curve duration), which measures the sensitivity of a bond’s price to a change in its own yield to maturity (not the benchmark yield curve).
answerFeedback.214768fb-2810-415c-bccf-0384ae714cc8: Correct because effective duration is a type of curve duration that measures the sensitivity of the bond price with respect to a benchmark yield curve.
answerFeedback.d84666eb-3c63-4f54-b54b-fe3903078eed: Incorrect because modified duration is a type of yield duration (as opposed to curve duration), which measures the sensitivity of a bond’s price to a change in its own yield to maturity (not the benchmark yield curve).

choices.itemBody: C. the price value of a basis point.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-27
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond:

Market Price  96.00
Market price if yields rise 1 basis point 95.92
Market price if yields fall 1 basis point 96.10

The price value of a basis point is:

answerFeedback.3f9441e4-2a9e-41d5-b57d-7ec081018535:
Incorrect because only the increase in yield side is used to calculate PVBP.

PVBP ≠ (PV – PV+)

≠ (96 – 95.92) = 0.08.
answerFeedback.8bdff524-a794-4d45-8273-4d8e7bb9d97c:
Incorrect because the 'divide by 2' is missing in the formula.

≠ (96.1 – 95.92) = 0.18.
answerFeedback.b83cebf9-74aa-4703-b593-9c0711b9be57:
Correct because the price value of a basis point (or PVBP) is an estimate of the change in the full bond price given a 1 bp change in the yield-to-maturity.

PVBP = (PV– – PV+)/2

= (96.1 – 95.92)/2 = 0.09.

entry.title: ITEM_20180516063
entry.itemBody: The convexity of putable bonds is:

answerFeedback.0e11f3e8-f7f4-4163-bb43-add4c50953d4: Correct. Putable bonds always have positive convexity.
answerFeedback.757722a1-baf5-45a6-9ea7-ed07f016c5f6: Incorrect because putable bonds always have positive convexity.
answerFeedback.becc3aed-7635-495c-b762-eb5b9c6b786a: Incorrect because putable bonds always have positive convexity.

choices.itemBody: B. negative for a decrease in yield.
C. negative for an increase in yield.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.09-Deriv-Ebeling-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following is used by clearinghouses to determine the daily gain and loss to the parties of a futures contract?

answerFeedback.39687c41-48e5-43c4-955c-e9ee119f6a86: Correct because the most important feature of futures contracts is the daily settlement of gains and losses and the associated credit guarantee provided by the exchange through its clearinghouse. At the end of each day, the clearinghouse engages in a practice called mark to market (MTM), also known as the daily settlement. The clearinghouse determines an average of the final futures trading price of the day and designates that price as the end-of-day settlement price. All contracts are then said to be marked to the end-of-day settlement price.
answerFeedback.72d52dc5-ccfd-445f-aa66-5500afae7e35: Incorrect because the maintenance margin is the amount of money that each participant must maintain in the account after the trade is initiated, and it is always significantly lower than the initial margin. Therefore, the maintenance margin covers any potential losses arising from the mark to market practice which has to occur first before any shortfall in the maintenance margin is calculated.
answerFeedback.9096ab32-73ea-4d60-afb9-3057f7130042: Incorrect because some futures contracts contain a provision limiting price changes. These rules, called price limits, establish a band relative to the previous day’s settlement price, within which all trades must occur. If market participants wish to trade at a price above the upper band, trading stops, which is called limit up, until two parties agree on a trade at a price lower than the upper limit. Likewise, if market participants wish to trade at a price below the lower band, which is called limit down, no trade can take place until two parties agree to trade at a price above the lower limit. Therefore, limit up and limit down refer to price limits but not to the practice that determines current gain and loss positions of futures contract parties.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.06-Alt-Kennan-14
entry.itemBody: In the private debt market, a hybrid loan structure that combines secured and unsecured debt into a single loan with a blended interest rate is best described as:

answerFeedback.480dd982-6cbb-4c87-a463-4e686a0add7c: Incorrect because a leveraged loan is a type of direct lending that typically does not blend secured and unsecured debt. The debt itself typically is senior and secured and has covenants in place to protect the lender/investor. In direct lending, many firms may also provide debt in the form of a leveraged loan, a loan that is itself levered. Private debt firms that invest in leveraged loans first borrow money to finance the debt and then extend it to another borrower.
answerFeedback.8c7633fa-0bad-4c97-943e-36b213e57c1d: Correct because this is the definition of unitranche debt. Another type of debt that could be directly extended to borrowers is unitranche debt. Unitranche debt consists of a hybrid or blended loan structure combining different tranches of secured and unsecured debt into a single loan with a single, blended interest rate.
