Since unitranche debt is a blend of secured and unsecured debt, its interest rate will generally fall in between the interest rates often demanded on secured and unsecured debt. The unitranche loan will usually be structured between senior and subordinated debt in priority ranking.
answerFeedback.eb7d85b1-292a-43d2-bc37-52cf8700a4b9: Incorrect because mezzanine debt is not a blend of secured and unsecured debt.  Mezzanine debt refers to private credit subordinated to senior secured debt but senior to equity in the borrower’s capital structure. Because of its typically junior ranking and its usually unsecured status, mezzanine debt is riskier than senior secured debt.

entry.title: ITEM_2019B PM 06KJG
entry.itemBody: The two-fund separation theorem states that all investors will hold a combination of the:

answerFeedback.277365a1-51bb-45d3-8e2d-e05ea07a5b78: Incorrect because the two-fund separation theorem states that all investors regardless of taste, risk preferences, and initial wealth will hold a combination of two portfolios or funds: a risk-free asset and an optimal portfolio of risky assets. The left-most point on the minimum-variance frontier is the portfolio with the minimum variance among all portfolios of risky assets, and is referred to as the global minimum-variance portfolio. While the investor will hold the risk-free asset in their portfolio, their risk-return trade-off can be improved by holding the optimal risky portfolio rather than the global minimum-variance portfolio.
answerFeedback.5c5478c8-7f83-418e-96ab-5517ea08f818: Incorrect because the two-fund separation theorem states that all investors regardless of taste, risk preferences, and initial wealth will hold a combination of two portfolios or funds: a risk-free asset and an optimal portfolio of risky assets. The left-most point on the minimum-variance frontier is the portfolio with the minimum variance among all portfolios of risky assets, and is referred to as the global minimum-variance portfolio. While the investor will hold the optimal risky portfolio, their risk return trade-off can be improved by holding the risk-free asset rather than the global minimum-variance portfolio.
answerFeedback.800681cf-e6df-4637-9775-33cfc3b5402e: Correct because the two-fund separation theorem states that all investors regardless of taste, risk preferences, and initial wealth will hold a combination of two portfolios or funds: a risk-free asset and an optimal portfolio of risky assets.

choices.itemBody: A. risk-free asset and the optimal risky portfolio.
B. risk-free asset and the global minimum-variance portfolio.
C. optimal risky portfolio and the global minimum-variance portfolio.

entry.title: ITEM_20170516008
entry.itemBody: The Gordon growth model is most appropriate for valuing the common stock of a dividend paying company that is:

answerFeedback.0618fc45-cbe5-450a-a82a-1884eabb1759: Incorrect. A two-stage dividend discount model would be appropriate for a company that is experiencing a higher than the sustainable growth rate.
answerFeedback.6e59a379-1b57-48e2-b802-989c4a0dcdd0: Correct. The Gordon growth model is most appropriate for valuing common stock of a dividend paying company that is mature and relatively insensitive to the business cycle or economic fluctuations.
answerFeedback.6ff0f36e-7e8c-4144-b5c0-b5ff6c9a1735: Incorrect. A three-stage dividend discount model would be most appropriate for a fairly young company that is just entering the growth phase.

choices.itemBody: A. young and just entering the growth phase.
B. mature and relatively insensitive to economic fluctuations.
C. experiencing growth that is higher than the sustainable growth rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-02463
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following balance sheet information (in $ millions) for a company:

Cash   2.5
Accounts receivable   7.5
Inventories 15.0
Net fixed assets 25.0
Total assets 50.0
Total liabilities 22.5
Common shareholders' equity 27.5
Total liabilities and equity 50.0

The market value of inventories is 110% of reported value and the market value of net fixed assets is 115% of reported value. All other values are as reported. There are 2.0 million shares outstanding and the current share price is $18.00. Using an asset-based valuation approach, the company's shares are most likely:

answerFeedback.238948bb-79d1-49b1-90e1-11923f9e124c: Incorrect because with an estimated value per share of $16.375, the shares are overvalued, not fairly valued or undervalued, because market price ($18.00) exceeds estimated value per share.
answerFeedback.28fb7974-6942-4427-8361-7fb9dc43630f: Incorrect because with an estimated value per share of $16.375, the shares are overvalued, not fairly valued or undervalued, because market price ($18.00) exceeds estimated value per share.
answerFeedback.368f2c55-023b-46fa-8f22-fa02a0e20678:
Correct because estimated value (adjusted book value) per share = adjusted book value / number of shares outstanding = (market value of assets – market value of liabilities) / number of shares outstanding.

Market value of assets = cash + accounts receivable + adjusted inventories + adjusted net fixed assets = 2.5 + 7.5+ (1.10 × 15.0) + (1.15 × 25) = 2.5 + 7.5 + 16.5 + 28.75 = 55.25.

Adjusted book value = 55.25 – 22.5 = 32.75.

Estimated value per share = 32.75 / 2.0 = $16.375.

With a current share price of $18.00, the shares are overvalued because market price exceeds estimated value per share.

entry.title: ITEM_20170421018
entry.itemBody: Based on historical returns, a portfolio has a Sharpe ratio of 2.0. If the mean return to the portfolio is 20%, and the mean return to a risk-free asset is 4%, the standard deviation of return on the portfolio is closest to:

answerFeedback.00cc4d48-e933-4e7c-8641-dbd98a4a2ba9: Incorrect. It adds the risk-free rate rather than subtracting it: (20% + 4%)/2 = 12%.
answerFeedback.0c55eea3-d9e9-431d-b7ce-45660717947d: Correct. The Sharpe ratio for a portfolio p, based on historical returns, is defined as S h = R ¯ p − R ¯ F s p where R ¯ p is the mean return to the portfolio, R ¯ F is the mean return to a risk-free asset, and sp is the standard deviation of return on the portfolio. In this instance, 2 = (20% − 4%)/sp. Solving for sp: sp = (20% − 4%)/2 = 8%.
answerFeedback.dfd9669a-c3ba-46bb-8349-7e299e411f36: Incorrect. It fails to subtract the risk-free rate: (20%)/2 = 10%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Conover-08
entry.itemBody: With respect to return-generating models, statistical factor models:

answerFeedback.6a4db65e-3f66-4075-90d7-64dd6d262c0f: Incorrect because in statistical factor models, the statistical factors, however, may or may not have an economic or fundamental connection to returns. Furthermore, in statistical factor models data mining may generate many spurious factors that are devoid of any economic meaning.
answerFeedback.735f677b-612a-423d-98a5-e2ca321a63ec: Incorrect because in statistical factor models, the statistical factors, however, may or may not have an economic or fundamental connection to returns. Furthermore, in statistical factor models data mining may generate many spurious factors that are devoid of any economic meaning.
answerFeedback.ba1d6a86-3277-458f-a52e-c2cb7aebf418: Correct because in a statistical factor model, historical and cross-sectional return data are analyzed to identify factors that explain variance or covariance in observed returns.

choices.itemBody: A. only include factors that have economic meaning.
B. identify factors that explain the covariance in observed returns.
C. only include factors that have a fundamental connection to returns.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10715
entry.itemBody:
A portfolio consists of two securities with the following characteristics:

  Expected Return Standard Deviation of Returns
Security 1 17% 24%
Security 2 6% 12%

If the portfolio has an expected return of 12.6% and the returns of the two securities are uncorrelated, the portfolio's standard deviation is closest to:

answerFeedback.27e64a3b-4135-4dfb-8304-e91ef6c0b2d1:
Incorrect because it assumes that, since the securities' returns are uncorrelated, the portfolio standard deviation is the weighted mean of the individual securities' standard deviations.

The portfolio's weights are calculated by setting the portfolio return equal to 12.6%. The portfolio return of a two-security portfolio is:

Rp = w1R1+ (1 – w1)R2

12.6% = w1 × 17% + (1 – w1) × 6%

w1= 0.6 and w2 = 1 – 0.6 = 0.4

Then, σp is incorrectly calculated as:

σp = 0.6 × 0.24 + 0.4 × 0.12

σp = 0.192 = 19.2%. This would be the correct portfolio standard deviation if the correlation was equal to 1.
answerFeedback.a3ca6c33-b0cd-486a-90c9-43664f355ce2:
Correct because the portfolio's weights are calculated by setting the portfolio return equal to 12.6%. The portfolio return of a two-security portfolio is:

Rp = w1R1 + w2R2

Rp = w1R1 + (1 – w1)R2

12.6% = w1 × 17% + (1 – w1) × 6%

w1 = 0.6 and w2 = 1 – 0.6 = 0.4

The variance of a two-security portfolio is:

σp2 = (w12σ12 + w22σ22 + 2w1w2Cov(R1, R2))>

Since the two securities' returns are uncorrelated, it follows that Cov(R1, R2) = 0, such that:

σp2 = (0.62 × 0.242 + 0.42 × 0.122)

σp2 = (0.0207 + 0.0023)

σp = √0.0230 = 0.1518 ≈ 15.2%.
answerFeedback.f604ede6-5fb4-4849-a01c-5874991fa853:
Incorrect because it uses an equally weighted portfolio of securities instead of deriving the securities' weights from the portfolio's expected return. Given that the two securities' returns are uncorrelated, it follows that the correlation between the two securities' returns is 0. Thus, portfolio standard deviation is calculated as:

σp2 = 0.52 × 0.242 + 0.52 × 0.122

σp2 = 0.0144 + 0.0036

σp2 = 0.018

σp = √0.018 = 0.1342 ≈ 13.4%.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10313
entry.itemBody: A financial system is best described as operationally efficient when:

answerFeedback.9a5ad5da-4776-4d8b-bc30-b4b88865a997: Incorrect because economies that use resources where they are most valuable are allocationally efficient.
answerFeedback.a9c8ecc8-0cb0-43fd-b96e-7179db7bc1da: Incorrect because if the prices of the assets and contracts reflect all available information related to fundamental values, the financial system is informationally efficient.
answerFeedback.b7016ef8-71f0-4eab-96dc-5dd58667ffb4: Correct because if the costs of arranging trades are low, the financial system is operationally efficient.

choices.itemBody: A. the costs of arranging trades are low.
B. asset and contract prices reflect all available information.
C. an economy's resources are used where they are most valuable.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-Deriv-Irvin-09
entry.itemBody: If futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates then futures contracts are mostly likely:

answerFeedback.70775119-fd37-496b-bd44-b1eba52c45fb: Incorrect because if futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, futures contracts are more desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards. The reason is because rising prices lead to futures profits that are reinvested in periods of rising interest rates, and falling prices leads to losses that occur in periods of falling interest rates. It is far better to receive cash flows in the interim than all at expiration under such conditions. This condition makes futures more attractive than forwards, and therefore their prices will be higher than forward prices.
answerFeedback.c1f4b019-de7c-4089-a14f-3baddb85b2ef: Incorrect because if futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, futures contracts are more desirable, not less desirable, to holders of long positions than are forwards. The reason is because rising prices lead to futures profits that are reinvested in periods of rising interest rates, and falling prices leads to losses that occur in periods of falling interest rates. It is far better to receive cash flows in the interim than all at expiration under such conditions. This condition makes futures more attractive than forwards, and therefore their prices will be higher than forward prices.
answerFeedback.f099f37c-86e0-4638-a664-8c6ad109bda7: Correct because if futures prices are positively correlated with interest rates, futures contracts are more desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards. The reason is because rising prices lead to futures profits that are reinvested in periods of rising interest rates, and falling prices leads to losses that occur in periods of falling interest rates. It is far better to receive cash flows in the interim than all at expiration under such conditions. This condition makes futures more attractive than forwards, and therefore their prices will be higher than forward prices.

choices.itemBody: A. less desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards.
B. more desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards.
C. neither more or less desirable to holders of long positions than are forwards.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10245
entry.itemBody: A security's market value and intrinsic value are most likely the same if:

answerFeedback.344119f7-1bee-4231-9234-54e304fccc85: Incorrect because the more complex an asset's future cash flows, the more difficult it is to estimate its intrinsic value.
answerFeedback.e6a99acc-6526-4cfe-8dcb-4995db0764c1: Incorrect because if active investment is profitable, this suggests the market is inefficient, in which case, market value and intrinsic value are most likely different. If investors believe an asset market is relatively inefficient, they may try to develop an independent estimate of intrinsic value.
answerFeedback.f3a42376-eb64-413e-bd9c-c4d5875a0e7d: Correct because if investors believe a market is highly efficient, they will usually accept market prices as accurately reflecting intrinsic value.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Barker-04
entry.itemBody: For a coupon bond with a positive yield, compounding more frequently within the year results in a yield-to-maturity that is:

answerFeedback.0087371b-f736-4501-8e78-307737ac0bff: Correct because for a given pair of cash flows, the stated annual rate and the periodicity are inversely related. Thus, increasing the frequency of compounding reduces the annual rate.
answerFeedback.ddb9fb08-b252-4df7-8326-e3bd63b3d198: Incorrect because for a given pair of cash flows, the stated annual rate and the periodicity are inversely related. Thus, increasing the frequency of compounding reduces the annual rate. The annual rate does not stay the same.
answerFeedback.f48e9d8b-84ab-4583-a4b7-c9c3832a6164: Incorrect because for a given pair of cash flows, the stated annual rate and the periodicity are inversely related. Thus, increasing the frequency of compounding reduces, not increases, the annual rate.

entry.title: ITEM_20170607101
entry.itemBody: The option-free bonds of Argus Corporation have a duration of eight years. When interest rates rise by 100 bps, the bond’s price declines by 7.9%. When interest rates fall by 100 bps, however, the price rises by 8.2%. The asymmetrical price change is most likely caused by the:

answerFeedback.142ee82a-a4ef-452a-8b21-89ab01ff76d2: Incorrect because the maturity effect relates to the sensitivity of bond price changes to the time to maturity.
answerFeedback.505c3f43-4548-4db8-91e7-1db7d392f521: Correct because a fall in interest rates will result in a higher percentage rise in the bond’s price compared with the percentage fall in the bond’s price when interest rates rise by the same amount.
answerFeedback.ec2af511-e8da-492a-b944-2421ac6470f0: Incorrect because the coupon effect relates to the sensitivity of bond price changes to changes in the coupon rate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Deriv-Lamba-14
entry.itemBody: In a binomial option pricing model, the expected payoff is based on:

answerFeedback.3715ba4b-dff5-4b7c-964e-8712d065e5c1: Incorrect because, as described in the rationale for the correct answer, the binomial option pricing model uses risk-neutral probabilities.
answerFeedback.6c1aae23-c7de-4214-b2a4-e6cebc12958a: Correct because the value of an option today is its risk-neutral expected value at maturity, discounted at the risk-free rate. The risk-neutral expected value is determined using risk-neutral probabilities.
answerFeedback.9b39b512-6d9d-49cd-b973-85018f078cea: Incorrect because, as described in the rationale for the correct answer, the binomial option pricing model discounts the expected payoff at the risk-free rate.

choices.itemBody: A. estimated probabilities and discounted at the risk-free rate.
B. risk-neutral probabilities and discounted at the risk-free rate.
C. risk-neutral probabilities and discounted at the risk-free rate plus a risk premium.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10290
entry.itemBody: In the portfolio management process, the decision whether to use a nominal or real return objective is most likely part of the:

answerFeedback.15a04489-77ce-476e-9136-cf1b34cd1f74: Incorrect because determination of the return objective is included in the preparation of the IPS, which is part of the planning, not execution, step. The execution step includes: (1) Asset allocation, (2) Security analysis, and (3) Portfolio construction.
answerFeedback.7e1da6ef-77f9-47ee-b8d3-0cced0e849b0: Incorrect because determination of the return objective is included in the preparation of the IPS, which is part of the planning, not feedback, step. The feedback step includes: (1) Portfolio monitoring and rebalancing, and (2) Performance measurement and reporting.
answerFeedback.8888d8fc-58ed-4bcc-ab89-5758d1633099: Correct because the planning step includes the preparation of an investment policy statement (IPS). One of the major components of an IPS is the return objective. Care should be taken that client and manager are in agreement on whether the return objective is nominal (which is more convenient for measurement purposes) or real (i.e., inflation-adjusted, which usually relates better to the objective).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-PM-Tomter-15
entry.itemBody: In relation to asset allocation, which of the following is a desirable property when specifying asset classes?

answerFeedback.75db4ee1-754e-4468-89ef-943528362393: Correct because when defining asset classes, a number of criteria apply. The asset classes, while being mutually exclusive, should add up to a sufficient approximation of the relevant investable universe.
answerFeedback.8944a903-85c6-46d9-b62a-35f4fde35f39: Incorrect because asset classes should contain homogeneous assets, not heterogeneous assets. When defining asset classes, a number of criteria apply. Intuitively, an asset class should contain relatively homogeneous assets while providing diversification relative to other asset classes.
answerFeedback.da88fb7e-d923-4996-9142-c19f7463613f: Incorrect because paired correlations of assets within an asset class should be high, not low. When defining asset classes, a number of criteria apply. In statistical terms, risk and return expectations should be similar and paired correlations of assets should be relatively high within an asset class but should be lower versus assets in other asset classes.

choices.itemBody: A. Asset classes should be mutually exclusive.
B. An asset class should contain heterogeneous assets.
C. Each asset class should be composed of assets with low paired correlations.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-PM-Glover-01
entry.itemBody: With respect to a client's investment policy statement, the set of exposures to the permissible asset classes that is expected to achieve the client's long-term objectives best describes the:

answerFeedback.77772956-01e1-455c-aca6-40d7c90976b3: Correct because the strategic asset allocation (SAA) is the set of exposures to IPS-permissible asset classes that is expected to achieve the client's long-term objectives given the client's risk profile and investment constraints.
answerFeedback.9d725e90-570f-405f-b970-5a74cdc987d0: Incorrect because security selection is an attempt to generate higher returns than the asset class benchmark by selecting securities with a higher expected return.
answerFeedback.d82a48bb-512d-419e-9050-0d8414e27bec: Incorrect because the tactical asset allocation is the decision to deliberately deviate from the policy exposures to systematic risk factors (i.e., the policy weights of asset classes) with the intent to add value based on forecasts of the near-term returns of those asset classes.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Equity-Grabe-06
entry.itemBody: When constructing an equity index, each company's weight in the index is dependent on its number of shares outstanding if the index is:

answerFeedback.0613c6c7-44c4-4674-addc-3ad6549615d4: Correct because in market-capitalization weighting, or value weighting, the weight on each constituent security is determined by dividing its market capitalization by the total market capitalization (the sum of the market capitalization) of all the securities in the index. Market capitalization or value is calculated by multiplying the number of shares outstanding by the market price per share.
answerFeedback.40318a70-f33a-4140-86d8-5624aee7d8c7: Incorrect because in price weighting, the weight on each constituent security is determined by dividing its price by the sum of all the prices of the constituent securities and not by market cap, which is price multiplied by shares outstanding.
answerFeedback.af6dd0d9-22a7-4134-9d44-fbaf4c997b5b: Incorrect because this method assigns an equal weight to each constituent security at inception and therefore the weight is not determined by market cap, which is price multiplied by shares outstanding.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-06414
entry.itemBody: The methodology used by a credit rating agency to adjust a specific bond issue rating is best described as:

answerFeedback.076bc1de-8dfb-47c8-aafd-1249b0b7a66b: Incorrect because although cross-default provisions, whereby events of default such as non-payment of interest on one bond trigger default on all outstanding debt, implies the same default probability for all issues, specific issues may be assigned different credit ratings - higher or lower - due to a ratings adjustment methodology known as notching. Notching is the process by which an issue credit rating is adjusted higher or lower, where as cross-default provisions describe a process whereby the default of a bond issue from the same issuer can trigger the default on other or all outstanding debt of that issuer. Cross-default provisions are terms in a bond issue and do not describe a credit rating methodology.
answerFeedback.7965ff0d-fbec-4854-ba57-bb43a250afde: Incorrect because a factor considered by ratings agencies is structural subordination, which can arise when a corporation with a holding company structure has debt at both its parent holding company and operating subsidiaries. Debt at the operating subsidiaries will get serviced by the cash flow and assets of the subsidiaries before funds can be passed ("upstreamed") to the holding company to service debt at that level. Recognizing these different payment priorities, and thus the potential for higher (or lower) loss severity in the event of default, the rating agencies have adopted a notching process whereby their credit ratings on issues can be moved up or down from the issuer rating. Notching is the process by which an issue credit rating is adjusted higher or lower, where as structural subordination is a factor that helps determine the notching outcome when a rating agency rates a bond issue.
answerFeedback.a59a3b04-36d0-47ad-b14b-22606987ba10: Correct because specific issues may be assigned different credit ratings - higher or lower - due to a ratings adjustment methodology known as notching. For the rating agencies, likelihood of default—default risk—is the primary factor in assigning their ratings. However, there are secondary factors as well including priority of payment in the event of a default, potential loss severity in the event of default, structural subordination,

entry.title: ITEM_2019B FI 01PJN
entry.itemBody: One source of return for an investor in a fixed-rate corporate bond is most likely the:

answerFeedback.1c0ee522-b962-4d4f-9bf6-cac510ebf3b4: Incorrect because the bid–offer spread or bid–ask spread, which reflects the prices at which dealers will buy from a customer (bid) and sell to a customer (offer or ask), is very often used as an indicator of liquidity, not a source of return for an investor.  The bid-ask spread may provide return for an intermediary such as a bank or broker selling the bond to the investor.
answerFeedback.9653f5cd-c273-45d7-aaff-ed325dc48154: Incorrect because in contrast to corporate bonds, the source of payment for ABS does not depend on the claims-paying ability of an operating entity but on the cash flows generated by one or more underlying financial assets, such as mortgages or auto loans. Interest on the collateral of the bond may be a source of return from certain ABS, but not from a typical fixed-rate corporate bond.
answerFeedback.ab63e848-8adb-41a7-bc7b-526f59d3db83: Correct because the fixed-rate bond investor has three sources of return: (1) receipt of the promised coupon and principal payments on the scheduled dates, (2) reinvestment of coupon payments, and (3) potential capital gains or losses on the sale of the bond prior to maturity.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Moustra-16
entry.itemBody: The price of a fixed-rate corporate bond with an annual modified duration of 6.32 increases from 90 to 95 per 100 of par value. If the government benchmark yield declines by 5 bps, the estimated decline in the spread over the benchmark yield is closest to:

answerFeedback.45e68f72-6b05-4554-b036-2c804105ad15: Incorrect because it correctly calculates the decline in the yield-to-maturity of 0.00879 but instead of subtracting the decline in the benchmark yield to calculate the decline in the spread, it adds it back, i.e. 0.00879 + 0.0005 = 0.00929.
answerFeedback.9b235581-9325-4ba8-bd26-7d68c9bba40a: Incorrect because it correctly calculates the decline in the yield-to-maturity of 0.00879 but omits to incorporate the effect of the government benchmark yield decrease, which means the decline in the spread over the benchmark yield is less than 87.9 bps, to have a total decrease in the yield-to-maturity of 87.9 bps.
answerFeedback.ef40f515-02ef-41d7-b974-9fa1a62af674:
Correct because given that the price increases to 95 from 90, the percentage price increase is (95 – 90)/(90) ≈ 0.05556. Using %ΔPVFull ≈ –AnnModDur × ΔYield, the change in the yield-to-maturity can be calculated as 0.05556 = –6.32 × ΔYield ⇒ ΔYield = –0.05556/6.32 ≈ –0.00879, i.e. a decrease of 0.00879.

Given that the yield-to-maturity on a corporate bond consists of a government benchmark yield and a spread, the decline in the government benchmark yield by 5 bps implies that the change in the spread over the benchmark yield is 0.00879 – 0.0005 = 0.00829, i.e. 82.9 bps, so that on a combined basis the decline in the yield-to-maturity is 0.0005 + 0.00829 = 0.00879.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Ng-18
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about REITs is most accurate?

answerFeedback.1f33f620-e0e5-45af-b380-754fb564a137: Correct because during certain market conditions, equity REIT correlations with market benchmarks increase, particularly during steep market downturns, such as the 2007–08 financial crisis. As these high correlations remained high during the post-crisis recovery, they lifted the value of most asset classes. Similar patterns in financial asset prices and real estate prices appear to have been observed during the COVID-19 recovery.
answerFeedback.26163bdb-cb8d-489e-a6c5-26b2927ab589: Incorrect because real estate historically has low correlations with other asset classes, and adding real estate to an investment portfolio provides diversification benefits at relatively lower levels of risk.
answerFeedback.abc71ae1-8e32-496b-ad9d-be578a52fa31: Incorrect because real estate historically has low correlations with other asset classes, and adding real estate to an investment portfolio provides diversification benefits at relatively lower levels of risk.

choices.itemBody: A. Adding real estate to a portfolio of traditional investments will increase portfolio risk
B. Adding real estate to a portfolio of traditional investments will decrease portfolio diversification
C. Equity REIT correlations with traditional investments are at their highest during steep market downturns

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Derivs-Kennan-02
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following data for a 2-year option contract:

Forward price 1.2000 USD/EUR
Strike price 1.2250 USD/EUR
Risk-free rate 5%
Call premium 0.0500 USD/EUR

USD/EUR is the amount of USD per 1 EUR

The put premium is closest to:

answerFeedback.2e62cf64-47be-4bba-b9ac-0c831ec4acee: Incorrect because this fails to take the present value of the strike price minus the forward price. In other words, it fails to divide by (1 + r)T in the equation p0 = c0 + [X – F0(T)] / (1 + r)T. This incorrect answer is calculated as p0 = 0.0500 + (1.2250 – 1.2000) = 0.0750.
answerFeedback.978eb724-3c77-447f-a151-1a2bbaaee8a2: Incorrect because this answer mistakenly flips the strike price and the forward price in the equation p0 = c0 + [X – F0(T)] / (1 + r)T. This incorrect answer is calculated as p0 = 0.0500 + (1.2000 – 1.2250) / (1 + 0.05)2 = 0.0273.
answerFeedback.b6ed96bf-0081-4004-b8c5-c30d396003f3:
Correct because put–call forward parity can be expressed as:

F0(T)(1 + r)-T + p0 = c0 + X(1 + r)-T,

where F0(T)(1 + r)-T is the present value of F0(T) discounted at the risk-free rate, p0 is the price of the put option on the underlying at t = 0, c0 is the price of the call option on the underlying at t = 0, X(1 + r)-T is a risk-free bond that pays the amount of the exercise price X at t = T.

In other words, under put–call parity, at t = 0 the price of the long underlying asset plus the long put must equal the price of the long call plus the risk-free asset.

Rearranging the formula yields:

F0(T)(1 + r)-T – X(1 + r)-T = c0 – p0

[F0(T) – X] / (1 + r)T = c0 – p0 

p0 = c0 + [X – F0(T)] / (1 + r)T

Substituting in yields:

p0 = 0.0500 + (1.2250 – 1.2000) / (1 + 0.05)2 = 0.0727.

entry.title: ITEM_20190531006
entry.itemBody: For non-amortizing, non-mortgage asset-backed securities, the lockout period most likely represents when:

answerFeedback.2507fd38-54e9-4e57-9324-f54141765a9b: Incorrect. When the lockout period is over, any principal that is repaid will not be used to reinvest in new loans but will instead be distributed to the bond classes.
answerFeedback.a850695f-cfb1-47b9-8304-fe8d9ffa57ee: Correct. The lockout period, or revolving period, is the period during which the principal repaid is reinvested to acquire additional loans with a principal equal to the principal repaid. When the lockout period is over, any principal that is repaid will not be used to reinvest in new loans but will instead be distributed to the bond classes. Overcollateralization refers to a reserve account, often an excess spread account.
answerFeedback.bca8d568-d7e6-4631-a9a0-19aae1382f76: Incorrect. Overcollateralization refers to a reserve account, often an excess spread account.

choices.itemBody: C. repaid principal is reinvested in loans of equal principal.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kashyap-26
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about a bond portfolio:

  Par Value Book Value Market Value Modified Duration
Bond 1 $700,000 $750,000

$770,000

 3
Bond 2

$825,000

$700,000

$850,000

 8

The portfolio's duration is closest to:

answerFeedback.25736a12-d6da-4b3d-a65b-f358cca9dc67:
Incorrect because book value was used instead of market value. The Macaulay and modified durations for the portfolio are calculated as the weighted average of the statistics for the individual bonds. The shares of overall portfolio market value are the weights.

≠ (750,000/1,450,000) x 3 + (700,000/1,450,000) x 8

= 1.5517 + 3.8621 = 5.4138 ≈ 5.4.
answerFeedback.bca9f6ba-9e60-4df3-aa53-584716e77995:
Incorrect because par value was used instead of market value. The Macaulay and modified durations for the portfolio are calculated as the weighted average of the statistics for the individual bonds. The shares of overall portfolio market value are the weights.

≠ (700,000/1,525,000) x 3 + (825,000/1,525,000) x 8

= 1.3770 + 4.3279 = 5.7049 ≈ 5.7.
answerFeedback.e2cadb54-757f-4487-b738-adf492cd78d1:
Correct because the Macaulay and modified durations for the portfolio are calculated as the weighted average of the statistics for the individual bonds. The shares of overall portfolio market value are the weights.

Portfolio Dur = (MV1/PMV)xDur1 + (MV2/PMV)xDur2

= (770,000/1,620,000) x 3 + (850,000/1,620,000) x 8

= 1.4259 + 4.1975 = 5.6234 ≈ 5.6.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-04219
entry.itemBody: An investor purchases common shares at €22 per share on margin and deposits just enough money to cover the 60% initial margin requirement. If the maintenance margin requirement is 25%, the share price below which the investor will first receive a margin call is closest to:

answerFeedback.8a92e9ff-f529-4ade-ade6-48092456dd28:
Correct because the investor deposits 60% of the purchase price (€13.20) as initial margin and borrows the balance (€8.80) from the brokerage company. The share price below which the investor will receive a margin call is computed as follows:

Price = borrowing/share divided by (1 – maintenance margin requirement)

€11.73 = €8.80 / (1 – 0.25).
answerFeedback.d9796819-e61b-4a61-9de4-79abd7486d1b:
Incorrect because the purchase price is multiplied by (1 minus the maintenance margin requirement).

€16.50 = €22 × (1 – 0.25).
answerFeedback.dd857fff-2869-4efe-9eb6-ac35e8633b71:
Incorrect because the amount borrowed is computed as 60% of the purchase price (€13.20).

€17.60 = €13.20 / (1 – 0.25).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.05-FI-Kassem-15
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about the forward curve for one-year rates:

Time Period Forward Rate
0y1y 1.20%
1y1y 1.88%
2y1y 2.46%
3y1y 2.93%

 

The price of a three-year, 5% annual-pay bond is closest to:

answerFeedback.59a24392-c0a6-48cf-90a0-76580239ea87: Incorrect because the bond also can be valued using the forward curve. This answer adds the total payments over the three years and divides by 3y1y. 115 / 1.02932.93 = 111.73.
answerFeedback.880a3e8e-d91f-4d38-9ab0-c6bf3b4aaf4d: Incorrect because the bond also can be valued using the forward curve. This answer incorrectly begins with the 1y1y forward rate, rather than the 0y1y rate.  5 / 1.0188 + 5 / (1.0188 × 1.0246) + 105 / (1.0188× 1.01246 × 1.0293) = 4.91 + 4.79 + 97.72 = 107.42 ≈ 107.4.
answerFeedback.a5d563ff-b9fa-4db0-b791-0d0a0b8aa560: Correct because the bond also can be valued using the forward curve. 5 / 1.012 + 5 / (1.012 × 1.0188) + 105 / (1.012 × 1.0188 × 1.0246) = 4.94 + 4.85 + 99.39 = 109.18 ≈ 109.2.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2021.07-Alts-Loo-07
entry.itemBody: An American waterfall distributes performance fees on a(n):

answerFeedback.0f76b40f-9004-43e8-8cee-57c01fc5e021: Incorrect because there are two types of waterfalls: deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls and whole-of-fund (or European) waterfalls. In contrast to deal-by-deal waterfalls, whole-of-fund waterfalls occur at the aggregate fund level (i.e., after all investments have been exited) and are more advantageous to the LPs.
answerFeedback.56ff0091-7ab3-4e5d-8d52-eb6e54d8dd15: Correct because there are two types of waterfalls: deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls and whole-of-fund (or European) waterfalls. Deal-by-deal waterfalls are more advantageous to the GP because performance fees are collected on a per-deal basis, allowing the GP to get paid before LPs receive both their initial investment and their preferred rate of return (i.e., the hurdle rate) on the entire fund.
answerFeedback.782b8e5b-1568-4113-86c1-363dcf9a8236: Incorrect because there are two types of waterfalls: deal-by-deal (or American) waterfalls and whole-of-fund (or European) waterfalls. In contrast to deal-by-deal waterfalls, whole-of-fund waterfalls occur at the aggregate fund level (i.e., after all investments have been exited) and are more advantageous to the LPs.

choices.itemBody: A. deal-by-deal basis and is more advantageous to the general partner than a European waterfall.
B. deal-by-deal basis and is more advantageous to the limited partners than a European waterfall.
C. aggregated fund level and is more advantageous to the limited partners than a European waterfall.

entry.title: ITEM_20170606081
entry.itemBody: A factor that most likely measures a client’s ability to bear risk is his or her:

answerFeedback.6e2f6b80-5a18-4a7d-a3e6-7e318ba9ecf2: Correct. A longer time horizon tends to imply greater ability to bear risk.
answerFeedback.a4fcef7a-560c-4c58-92a9-41d9850019ec: Incorrect. Personality type gives an indication about the willingness (not ability) of a client to bear risk.
answerFeedback.c3aa4036-be73-412b-b726-b285623d59af: Incorrect. Inclination to independent thinking gives an indication about the willingness (not ability) of a client to bear risk.
